results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 30-42 - SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

results.description:
OK this time, we shall dispense with the usual superfluous drivel in the description. Our theme here shall be the following by Shakespeare's Fool in the play King Lear to Lear when Lear had just discovered what his daughters had been conspiring to do. The Fool is desperately trying to cheer him up,

Mark it, nuncle:

Have more than thou showest,
Speak less than thou knowest,
Lend less than thou owest,
Ride more than thou goest,
Learn more than thou trowest,
Set less than thou throwest;
Leave thy drink and thy whore,
And keep in-a-door,
And thou shalt have more
Than two tens to a score.

Well this is advice from man to man however, it is generic across the board, and arguably goes strait to the point about all kinds of things. It is especially ironic because, Goneril and her sister use it as a philosophy. And they used it to defeat Lear.

I want you to use the comments section to get a conversation going. Nerds have so many thoughts, & so much curiosity which got them there at the Nerd level, I don't think that is going to be a hard thing to do. So get the discussion started, & let the Nerd Fun Intellectual Snobbery begin.

The advice the fool gives and the following are absolutely timeless (so I argue) and great advice also in this age,

Here is father Polonius giving son Laertes his best advice, in Hamlet, as Laertes is about to set sail: http://www.readwritethink.org/files/resources/lesson_images/lesson372/PoloniusExcerpt.pdf
results.how_to_find_us: Reserved area at the LOWER bar where the "tall" tables are

results.description:
Interested in expanding your homeschooling connections and resources by joining a weekly family coop? We are a community of eclectic homeschooling families with whom you can share your journey. 

We offer many opportunities for social interaction with adults and children from birth through the teen years. Each coop day offers several study groups in a wide range of topics from math & science to the arts and recreational sports and anything else we can dream up. We also have a high school level mock trial team and social activities like dances and game nights for your teens and tweens and events for the whole family. We have a lot of fun and sometimes even find friends for life!

Come check out Voyagers!

Questions? Email [masked]

See Upcoming Events at Voyagers: <a>www.voyagersinc.org.</a>

Voyagers, Inc. is a secular, volunteer-based nonprofit 501(c)3 organization established to commit its resources to activities which are intended to benefit children, including gifted children, who are home schooled.

results.description:
***** Just a reminder to update your RSVPs if they have changed- and also to disclose that I do have one cat if anyone has cat allergies. See the YESses on Sunday!****

Barbera is an Italian grape that is the most heavily planted varietal in the Piedmont region. Historically treated as the ugly stepsister of Nebbiolo, this delicious grape and the captivating wine it produces has recently in the last generation come to prominence on its own for its vibrancy, high acidity, juiciness, and all flavors of alluring black fruits.  When you walk through the tables of Piedmont, more often than not diners are enjoying their food with a glass of Barbera. We're going to enjoy it with some delicious artisanal pizza.

Mostly identified with the towns of Asti, Alba, and Monferrato, Barbera is also grown in California, Washington, and parts of South America.

Bring 1 bottle of Barbera wine around the $20 range, 4 glasses in order to taste/judge the wines, and $10.00 for the food kitty towards the pizza and tiramisu, and any other snacks you want to throw in the mix!
results.name: BARBERA BLIND TASTING .. and Pizza!

results.description:
During the November Dinner, Art, + Music night at Miranda’s Hearth, hear from a panel of local artists discussing how they make a living as an artist. Our panel currently includes:

Emily Garfield is local artist and board member of Artisan’s Asylum. Emily creates intricate maps of imaginary places that explore the origins of cities and the function of maps themselves. Her drawings are inspired by the visual language of maps and the fractal similarity that cities share with biological processes such as the patterns of cells and neurons.

Joetta Maue is a full time artist primarily using photography and fibers. Her most recent body of work is a series of embroideries and images exploring intimacy & the domestic space. Joetta received her BFA from the Ohio State University and MFA from the University of Massachusetts. Her work has been shown in galleries and museums across the country & internationally.

Dena Haden is a visual artist who works with a variety of media, including sculpture, drawing, painting and installation. She was born and raised on Cape Cod and earned her BFA in Painting and Illustration from the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth. She attended the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia earning her MFA in 2008. Dena has instructed painting and design courses for several years at nonprofit organizations and private institutions and has developed valuable leadership and communication skills through teaching.

As always, the feature will be followed by a jam session and a potluck. Tickets are $7 or bring a potluck dish and get in for free!

This month, you can buy tickets ahead of time here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/making-a-living-as-an-artist-tickets-19118088718
results.name: Making a Living as an Artist

results.description:
This event is a combination of a Match Live event and Speed Dating.  Join other fun and friendly singles for a casual and comfortable singles party that you won't want to miss.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$20 ADMISSION INCLUDES:

*Light Appetizers

*Ice Breaker

*Amex Gift Cards for Ice Breaker Winners

*Supplies/Name Tags

PRE-PAY HERE: http://mixnmatchboston.eventbrite.com

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Here is how it works..

-Upon arrive you will be given a name tag with your code name and number..

-You will also be given a sheet where you can keep track of everyone you meet.

-We will have an ice breaker games throughout the night where you will have a chance to meet others at the event and write down the code names and numbers of those you wish to make a connection with.

-At the end of the night write down the names and the numbers of the people that you met and would like to see again.  You will then hand in your sheet and we will send you the contact info for all the people who have a mutual match with you! You will be able to choose up to 10 people for potential matches.

The Night Will Feature:

Ice Breaker game with prizes -Full menu is available (pay as you go)  -Music played at conversational levels

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will be coming on their own. 

 What are the age ranges? This event will cater mostly to 20's-late 30's's.
results.name: Singles Mix & Match Happy Hour- Ages 25-42 -Almst Full for Men

results.description:
It's week 7 of the 2015 Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing. FREE: The comedy club experience is called the Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing Company. The brewery and destination-taproom, which opened in April of 2105, opens Sunday nights as a showcase style stand-up comedy club open to the public 21+ with no cover charge or ticket fee. Guests are able to order charcuterie boards, dinner and pints during, before and after the show. With a Sunday night show time of 9PM there is ample free parking is available.

Season 1, the 2015 dates are as follows: September 13th, 20th and 27th, October 4th, 11th and 25th, November 1st 8th 15th and 22nd December 6th 13th 20th and 27th.

The opening night on September 6th filled to capacity and guests were entertained by 7 professional comedians and show host C.J. Browne. “We’re excited to offer a curated show of experienced local comedians. Since the room and setup require excellence the showcase is not an open mic night. We are absolutely psyched about the success of opening night. We played to a full house that loved the show.” Show performer Gary Peterson says “The Slumbrew comedy show was such a fun room to work, because the owners care about making it fun. A packed house of young heroes supporting the local scene makes this place special. It makes me happy to know something so cool is alive in Somerville.”
results.name: Liquid Courage November 8'th

results.description:
Moose Hill is Mass Audubon’s oldest and largest wildlife sanctuary, encompassing protected forests, fields, and wetlands. Diverse hiking trails and a red maple swamp boardwalk provide countless opportunities for exploration.

We will be hiking the Kettle/Pine/Ovenbird trails for a challenging loop walk along hilly terrain which will take about 2 hours. On this oldest part of the sanctuary, you may find signs of a dam and seasonal stream, an old rhododendron garden, and a kettle hole left behind by part of a melting glacier.


Please dress appropriately for the weather conditions. Dressing in layers works best. Wear appropriate footwear for hiking, bring some snacks, and water


We will meet inside the visitors center. There is a $4.00 trail fee unless you are a member of Mass Audubon. Sorry, no dogs allowed at this venue.


If you have any trouble finding our meetup location please feel free to call before the event kicks off. Debbi's cell phone is[masked]-5864.

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below. Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment.

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: Moose Hill Wildlife Sanctuary

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
SYNOPSIS:


What Freddie Steinmark (Finn Wittrock) wants most in the world is to play football. Deemed too small by the usual athletic standards, his father trains him hard, and Freddie brings a fight to the game that ultimately gets him noticed — by none other than legendary University of Texas coach Darrell Royal (Aaron Eckhart). Awarded a scholarship and a chance to play for the Longhorns, Freddie sets off to Austin with his loving high school sweetheart Linda (Sarah Bolger), determined to make the team. Alongside his old teammate Bobby Mitchell (Rett Terrell) and new pal James Street (Juston Street), Freddie is put through the paces of a grueling practice schedule, but the boys' camaraderie off the field translates into solid playing on it, and they rise up the depth charts, giving the Longhorns a real chance to turn the team around. But just when they’re reveling in the success of the season, Freddie suffers an injury that leads to a shocking diagnosis and the biggest challenge he will ever face. From the writer of HOOSIERS and RUDY, MY ALL AMERICAN tells the true story of a boy who became a hero and what it truly means to have the heart of a champion.

https://youtu.be/QTahmkL8QzM
results.name: My All American (Monday November 9th at 7PM - AMC Boston)

results.description:
We're getting together for a 1 hour open table conversation; where attendees talk with each other and discuss current security issues. Tonight's topic will be security compliance. We all know the problems with compliance (i.e. its overwhelming, time consuming, and nobody likes being told what to do), but few know how to actually get it done. 

We'll share war stories about the compliance burdens that Sysadmins/Security Engineers face as well as the snake oil that currently exists in the industry. If you're having to face PCI-DSS, ISO 27002, FEDRAMP, HIPAA, SOC 2, then this discussion is for you!

The room is a bit on the smaller side. We ask that if you're recruiting or sales, please sit this one out!

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

results.description:
On November 9th, StoryCode Boston, GreenDoorLabs and MIT Open Documentary Lab present a story gaming exercise from Sherlock Holmes and the Internet of Things, an ongoing collaboration that plays with ideas of authorship and smart objects through narrative experiments inspired by the world of the eponymous detective.

At our meetup we'll divide the group into teams who'll each create a Holmes-ian "crime scene" for another team to solve.  We'll also review the results of the Sherlock Holmes IOT global challenge and discuss how potential connected 'smart' objects could be used as storytelling tools.

Sherlock Holmes IOT initiated at Columbia University's Storytelling Lab earlier this year and now has participating groups around the world who have been working for months to create a massive connected crime scene using "smart objects" as storytelling tools. The first phase of the project will culminate during a global challenge October 24 - 25.

This is only the beginning, as the team at Columbia intends to use the team results and experiences from the first challenge to take the project to new heights next year. The coolest part is that anyone can contribute to the evolution of this project and we certainly intend to :)

results.name: Sherlock Holmes & the Internet of Things

results.description:
What do you need to thrive as a talent sourcer today?  It's called the Modern Sourcer's Toolkit, and it's a set of best practice methods and tools compiled and explained by one of today's top industry consultants/trainers.

The Boston Area Talent Sourcing Association is pleased to have from RecruitingToolbox.com and recruiting leader, Carmen Hudson, explain it all with the modern sourcer's toolkit.  Coming from Seattle, this will be Carmen's only free public sourcing presentation in the Boston area this year!

Also featuring a couple of rotating rounds of our famous peer-to-peer networking sessions on your choice of sourcing subtopics, moderated by expert local practitioners.

Get details or pre-register free while seats remain at http://batsa5.eventbrite.com (while you can RSVP here on MeetUp, your seat is not guaranteed unless you also pre-register on EventBrite.)

More about Carmen:

Carmen Hudson draws from over 15 years of recruiting experience, with a strong focus on helping organizations attract, source and recruit top talent. Carmen’s expertise is in helping clients build the right sourcing and recruiting strategies, and then implementing them in the real world of limited budgets, competing priorities, and highly competitive recruiting environments. She consults and trains companies to help them leverage high ROI solutions for big sourcing, social media, and technology implementation initiatives.

Carmen is a self-described “recruiting geek” who has spent years learning, creating, and sharing best practices around sourcing. She gets that technology – for all of its hype – is still a means to an end, not an end in itself. Her corporate experience includes Yahoo!, where she was Senior Manager, Talent Acquisition. At Yahoo! she led the strategic sourcing team, revitalizing the employee referral program and Yahoo’s employer brand. The team was awarded a coveted Yahoo! Superstar Award, an ERE Excellence award and various recruiting and advertising industry awards. Prior to joining Yahoo!, she was manager, Global Strategic Sourcing for Starbucks Coffee Corporation, where she developed sourcing strategies and recommended resources and tactics to support U.S. retail management hiring. She has also held senior talent acquisition roles at Microsoft, Amazon.com and Capital One and founded a social recruiting technology company.

Carmen is a regular contributor to recruiting industry publications, including ERE and Recruiting Trends. She is a frequent speaker at recruiting events, including the Social Recruiting Summit, Kennedy Online Recruiting Conference, SourceCon, Talent42, and the Seattle Staffing Management Association. She is also the co-founder of Talent42.  Carmen earned a degree in journalism from Northwestern University.
results.how_to_find_us: corner of Channel and Iron Streets off "A" St. in Boston's Fort Point Channel area (4 min. walk from Broadway T stop on the Red line)
results.name: Register for BATSA 5: the Modern Sourcer's Toolkit with Carmen Hudson

results.description:
Socializing for Justice is proud to be a City Awake partner and host this event during the[masked]-day City Awake Festival. Learn more at www.cityawake.is/festival.

Ready to move from hosting "friendraisers" to hosting fundraisers? Join Socializing for Justice for a ProfDev training on Tools and Tips for Successful Fundraising Events on Monday, November 9, 6:00 - 8:30 PM.

Fee: $10 advance/$20 door - split with trainer
Limited space - register ahead of time: www.sojust.org
Credit cards accepted online. Cash only at the door (if space available).
Newcomers always welcomed!

Tools and Tips for Successful Fundraising Events
This training will focus on the choreography and best practices needed to solicit at an event. You'll learn many different ways to raise money through events: tickets, sponsorships, on-site ask, live auction, silent auction, and raffles. To stay on track as you plan and build on past successes, you'll receive training on how to use an event timeline, event strategy form, and write an event summary. Participants will receive a handout filled with resources to help them run their own successful fundraising event.

ABOUT OUR PRESENTER 
Robbie Samuels has been recognized as a networking expert by Inc. and Lifehacker, and profiled in "Stand Out: How to Find Your Breakthrough Idea and Build a Following Around It" by Dorie Clark. Since 2009, his engaging and fun presentations have helped a wide array of audiences increase their confidence when it comes to relationship-building - whether through networking, fundraising, or sales. He passionately believes everyone should stop wasting time networking and shares how through his signature session, “Art of the Schmooze.” 


Over the last decade, as Senior Manager of Events and Donor Engagement at GLAD, Robbie coordinated up to 25 fundraisers and donor cultivation events a year. These fundraisers raised nearly one million dollars annually (25% of GLAD's budget).


In 2006, he founded Socializing for Justice (SoJust.org) to build a cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community and network in Boston based on the philosophies of abundance and radical inclusion. In recognition of his social justice work, Boston City Council named his birthday "Robbie Samuels Day" in 2011. Learn about Robbie and his work at www.RobbieSamuels.com

SCHEDULE
6:00-6:30 Socializing -  bring your own dinner
 6:30-8:30 Training and Q&A

*  DIRECTIONS - The NonProfit Center is located one block from South Station at 89 South Street. The Center is physically accessible through the main lobby.

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!
Invite your friends to the Facebook event.
Join the SoJust Facebook group: http://on.fb.me/SoJust
On Twitter? Follow @SoJust and SoJust's Co-Founder @RobbieSamuels #sojust
_________________________________________________________ 
Socializing for Justice - www.sojust.org
Since 2006, we've been building this great sandbox where we can bring progressives of all stripes together and try out new ideas in this "Movement Moment". Spaces like this are crucial as we start to reframe and build new visions for our movement(s).

SoJust hosts events that draw progressives of all stripes that share common values but may work on different issues. We host monthly socials that allow for the possibility of cross-issue connections and run a monthly ProfDev Series, hosted by The NonProfit Center, which provides access to affordable professional development to increase our individual capacity for movement building.

With over 2800 members and 9 years of creating a diverse cross-issue community in Boston (200+ events!), Socializing for Justice is the best place to find the great people, organizations and community you're looking for while putting the SOCIAL back in social justice.

YES, WE MEAN YOU. We've got members of all ages, races, genders, sexual orientations, levels of activism and professions. We hope you see someone like yourself and meet someone you otherwise wouldn't have.
results.name: ProfDev: Tools and Tips for Successful Fundraising Events

results.description:
Dr. Suzanne Paradis:
Making and Breaking Connections in the Developing Brain

Join us on November 9thth at 7:00pm at the Burren, for Science by the Pint.

How is the brain is put together to control the most basic functions of the human body? How are we able to move our arms and legs, to learn and remember, to see and hear? The adult human brain contains a massive network of neurons that communicate with one another to control these tasks. Neurons talk to other neurons through synapses:  specialized sites of cell-to-cell contact. Synapses come in two flavors: excitatory, which promotes information propagation through networks, and inhibitory, which prevents it. The billions of neurons in the human brain form trillions of synapses, ensuring proper information flow in the brain.

Many disorders of the nervous system – such as epilepsy and Autism – occur when neurons fail to form appropriate synaptic connections or when communication between neurons breaks down at the synapse. To understand what goes awry in these disorders, we must first understand how synapses are assembled in the typically developing nervous system. Dr. Paradis’ research explores the topic of synapse development and how disruptions to this process might underlie human neurological disorders.


Science by the Pint is sponsored by an organization of Harvard graduate students called Science in the News.  In between their sleepless hours of hard work at Harvard Med School, they bring cutting edge scientific research to the public in a fun and informal format. 


The Burren is located on Elm Street right in the heart of Davis Square, just a short walk from the Red Line stop.  If you prefer to drive, there are metered spots on the street and in nearby municipal lots (see link below).  Meters are active until 8:00 PM, and metered spots are free thereafter. Municipal lot meters are good for three hours, and street spots are good for two.

Links:

SITN Facebook Page

SITN: Science by the Pint

The Burren

Davis Square Parking

For the November meeting, we will discuss the recent elections in the state and the special elections up-coming. We will also discuss the upcoming Presidential Primary election process.

We will also be discussing the End Common Core MA Ballot Initiative.  We have through November 17th to gather the 100,000 raw signatures (to reach 65,000 certified signatures) to get the question on the ballot. We will be looking for volunteers to make a final push to gather signatures and to spread the message about what a set back Common Core is for the state of Massachusetts.

There are other ballot initiatives – people are encouraged to come, advocate and gather signatures for, and recruit volunteers for those as well.

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.


BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:


1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.  Finally, if there are unusual circumstances, you can send Tucker a message.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

Update (10/15): In order to accommodate more people in the room, and maintain an easygoing environment for conversation and game playing, we ask that you please save loud games (like those with real-time arguing) for later in the evening, when the room is less full.  Typically this means 9:30 or later.


OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q. What About X-Wing?
A. If you noticed, this spot is filling up the time previously scheduled for X-Wing Miniatures 100pts - so... as you may have guessed, Randy and I will be setting up a couple of x-wing miniatures tables for those of us inclined towards that game but still want to make the event more inclusive to other game genres (it is not often the wife allows me to invite my friends to play games, so I better make the best use of the time).

Are you ready to take an inner journey of self-discovery? 


Then join Drew Scott Pearlman, as he introduces his New Program, The Four Faces of Transformation Workshop. During this workshop, you will discover your highest self and deepest purpose as you elevate through the four faces of transformation, from stranger and addict to visionary and lover. We will share empowering ideas and strategies to take your life in a new direction.  In this lively 90 minute workshop setting, you will move your body, meditate, utilize powerful journal writing exercises to deepen your self-awareness and much more.  


To learn more about The Four Faces of Transformation, please visit our website:

www.GreatLessonStudios.com


About Drew:  

Drew Scott Pearlman is a writer, speaker and filmmaker who has dedicated his life to inspiring and empowering audiences throughout the world. Drew is the creative force behind The Great Lesson, a film about the power of mind and body as well as The Healing Effect, a film about the healing power of food. He has presented his work at TEDX, Brandeis, Whole Foods as well as Yoga Studios, Organic Farms and Natural Living Stores across the country.

All of Drew's work culminates in his latest E-Course program called The Four Faces of Transformation. This 6 week e-course blends audio, video, text as well as live teleseminars to guide students on an inner journey of self-discovery and transformation.

Drew also offers personalized life coaching via Skype as well as at live workshops. You can learn more about these coaching opportunities by contacting him: [masked]

Hope to see you here

Ellen Sklaver, PSYCH-K & NLP Practitioner

results.description:
Join us for a unique, roundtable style exploration about how the way we breathe affects how we live our lives.

Our Format This Evening

We'll be experimenting with a new "Explorations" model for this Heartbeat Salon, where we will invite a special guest (Katrina!) to share the leading edge of her thinking on a particular topic that is alive and rich for her right now.

Tonight, wellness coach and massage therapist, Katrina Piehler, will be inviting us to explore with her a topic that is especially alive for her right now, one that has been inspiring her lately to ask questions such as: 

• Am I breathing well? 

• Do I know if I am or am not? 

• How can I tell? 

• What does it matter?

If adjusting how you breathe would make a difference in your life, would you know what adjustments to make, and how to begin?

In Katrina’s work over the past 12 years as a massage therapist, she has noticed that so many of us really have quite shallow, restricted breathing - and we don’t even realize it. 

What she has also seen, as a wellness coach, is that our capacity to do things like manage stress or tap into our resiliency for healthy, empowered living is literally affected by what our relationship with our breath is like.

Recently Katrina has been exploring the ideas and offerings in the book Free your Breath, Free your Life by Dennis Lewis. She is eager to share some of these ideas, combined with her own insights and thoughts, about bringing empowering awareness to this topic. 

So in this Heartbeat Salon Exploration, we invite you to come be part of a dynamic conversation about this topic. 

Engage in some of the exercises and ideas Katrina will share. Ask questions and provide your own insights as we co-create this exploration of how our relationship with our breath affects our lives.


To Prepare...


Before our gathering, take some time to notice your own breathing. 

Notice if there times throughout your day when you find yourself holding your breath, or times when you have a desire to take a deep breath. 

Pay attention, perhaps, to the parts of your body that move, or don’t move, when you notice your breathing. 

Here’s a link from Dennis Lewis’ website to a Take a Break: Sense your Breathing exercise you might try if you are interested.

Our Special Guest This Evening

Katrina Piehler is a PGN organizer and a certified Wellness Coach, Bodyworker & Workshop Facilitator. Positive psychology and the law of attraction are foundational concepts that both guide her personal life and inform her work. 

In 2003 she founded Living from Center- a massage therapy and wellness coaching practice whose mission is to help busy people shift from feeling stressed out, overwhelmed and discontented in their lives --to feeling re-connected to their vitality, tuned in to their own wisdom, & empowered to create lives they love living!

results.description:
Hey fellow Social Fun members, 

Don't you like to easily meet new professionals? 

Wouldn't you like to do good at the same time? 

Join us as we take our message of a clean and just energy future for Massachusetts to the State House!  Our legislators are making key decisions about the energy future of our Commonwealth — more fossil fuel infrastructure or more renewable energy?  Do you believe in better? Will all our MA communities have a share in a clean energy transition?  Let's fight against global warming. Let's fight for local jobs. We will rally at 10am at the Grand Staircase in the State House and then fan out in delegations to meet with our legislators.  Come just for the rally or stay and meet with your legislator.  Please sign up to let us know that you will be there! 

Please take a moment to register. 

Learn more: 

Click here to sign up for Nov. 10 Legislative Action Day 

A couple more popular Meetups will be joining us. 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers 

Don't you like Adventure: Brookline Community

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

Afterwards we'll walk to one of my favorite Beacon Hill restaurants. It's only a couple blocks away. 

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the Grand Staircase, 2nd Floor, MA State House, 24 Beacon Street. I'll provide my cell for your convenience.
results.name: Interfaith Action Day at the State House for a Clean + Favorite Restaurant!

In the spirit of the Thanksgiving Holiday Season, we ask, if you could, to please bring a canned good that will be donated to The Greater Boston Food Bank.

SHORT LIST OF MOST DESIRED FOOD ITEMS:

Dairy: Milk - dried, evaporated, and boxed (such as Parmalat)
Protein: Beef stew, nuts, peanut butter, beans, and peas (dried or canned), chili, tuna fish, chicken, salmon (canned)
Vegetables: Tomato sauce, diced tomatoes, spaghetti sauce, vegetables (canned), tomato juice
Fruit: Raisins and other dried fruit, applesauce, any canned fruit in its own juice
Grains: Crackers, oatmeal, whole grain rice, all types of pasta, ready to eat low sugar/high fiber cereal (Cheerios, Raisin Bran, etc.)

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Tuesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
--->NOTE: This is a FREE DIGITAL EVENT at your location on your device where-ever you are! Requires O'Reilly account registration & Adobe Flashplayer download to attend On24 webinar. 

REGISTER NOW: http://bit.ly/1Gi0Znk

In today's always-connected world, users expect to have a mobile experience that is immediate, pervasive, and aware. In this way, it is crucial to build apps that meet these expectations. Specifically, your business needs to build mobile apps that are always available, regardless of network connectivity and speed.

Users expect a great experience when using their mobile apps. If an app doesn't provide this, then users won't use it — it's that simple. In the past, this has mostly meant a beautiful and intuitive interface, which is important but not the whole story.

In this webcast, you'll learn how to build a mobile app that has a consistent user experience, both online and offline. This includes:

Syncing the data

Storing the data

Securing the data

Cross platform data modeling

You'll walk away with an understanding of the design patterns required to build an app that works online and offline — all this, using open source technologies.

About Wayne Carter, Chief Architect Mobile — Couchbase

Wayne is the Chief Architect of Mobile at Couchbase, where he is responsible for leading vision, strategy and development for the company's mobile solutions.

Before Couchbase, Wayne spent 7 years at Oracle as the Architect responsible for driving mobile innovation within the CRM and SAAS product lines. He has 10 patents and patents pending from his work there. Prior to Oracle, Wayne held technical leadership positions at Siebel working on their CRM product line.


About Ali LeClerc, Product Marketing Manager, Mobile — Couchbase

Ali is the Product Marketing Manager for Couchbase Mobile, where she manages and executes the worldwide marketing strategy for their mobile products. She joined Couchbase in 2011 to drive open source product adoption and awareness. Prior to Couchbase, Ali held marketing positions at Time Warner. She holds a degree from Yale University in Political Science.

results.description:
Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org) delivers fresh (rescued) produce to about 50 sites (only some are made public and publicized), and they hope to add MORE sites.

Each site is hosted by a local organization (mostly nonprofits, but some are for-profit residences).

Each site needs unpaid volunteers to help (a) unload the truck(s), (b) set up the tables and produce (in order by weight, from heavy to light), and (c) bag the produce into standard bags, which each sites 'neighbors' will come by (during the 'open' period) and take for $2/bag.

Most sites get freshly-baked bread (baked fresh that morning).

Volunteers get to take home one or two bags for themselves and 1-2 loaves of bread, also - because they volunteered.

To volunteer, in-mail the Meetup event host and say specifically which site and which date and time interests you (so that you can be registered in advance as a volunteer). In that in-mail, please provide your ACTUAL e-mail address, real full name, and phone number.

Please bring lots of extra used but clean and reusable plastic bags for the bagging.

Bring with you some means for transporting your own 'comped' produce home with you.
results.name: Volunteer for $2 Bag of Vegetarians - or get a $2 Bag for Yourself

results.description:
THE 33
Release Date:

November 13, 2015
Rating:

PG-13


Synopsis:

In 2010, the eyes of the world turned to Chile, where 33 miners had been buried alive by the catastrophic explosion and collapse of a 100-year-old gold and copper mine. Over the next 69 days, an international team worked night and day in a desperate attempt to rescue the trapped men as their families and friends, as well as millions of people globally, waited and watched anxiously for any sign of hope. But 200 stories beneath the surface, in the suffocating heat and with tensions rising, provisions—and time—were quickly running out. A story of resilience, personal transformation and triumph of the human spirit, the film takes us to the Earth’s darkest depths, revealing the psyches of the men trapped in the mine, and depicting the courage of both the miners and their families who refused to give up. Based on the gripping true story of survival—and filmed with the cooperation of the miners, their families and their rescuers—The 33 reveals the never-before-seen actual events that unfolded, above and below ground, which became nothing less than a worldwide phenomenon.

results.description:
- 6:00 PM to 6:30 PM - Networking

- 6:30 to 8:00 PM - Talk by Gerard Dwan

- Data and Video Games: How have video games influenced our view of data?   From early computers, to the arcade, to Atari, to Nintendo and the latest PlayStation, video games have been leveraging and displaying data. Whether it’s a high score, completion percentage, lap time, or equipment stat, data has been a huge part of the way we play. Take a tour of games, old and new, and how they have influenced us in the best and worst practices of data utilization.   

- Speaker Bio: Gerard Dwan is an Informationist at Knowledgent, a data and analytics firm with an office in Boston. There he specializes in bringing Big Data to Big Business. He also leads the Enterprise Search Competency for Financial Services and Insurance. Prior to this, he was the Manager of Solution Architecture at Attivio, leading a team of technical problem solvers responsible for the design and validation of client solutions. Prior to his management role he was a Solution Architect at Attivio helping large companies obtain analysis and understanding of their big data and content.
results.name: Data and Video Games: How have video games influenced our view of data?

Are you an avid skier, snowboarder, or winter sports enthusiast looking for the right workout to supplement your winter hobbies? Join me, Laura Loewy, of Backcountry Yoga for a powerful yoga and strength training series that will focus on preparing your body for snow sports. results.description:
Our next meeting will be presented by Scott Burke from IMAGINiT Technologies. below is a summary of his presentation.

The Future is Now: Virtual Collaboration in the AEC Space

Real-Time Collaboration are the new buzzwords in the Design and Construction World.  BIM is now more about working together in a truly collaborative environment.  Even now our clients are not only asking for it they are demanding it.  During this session we will explore a few tool available now, that truly support the collaborative workflow.  The first tool we will talk about is using Autodesk’s cloud based “Collaboration for Revit” tool.  A team oriented tool that allows a cloud based workflow on Revit projects.  The second tool we will talk about is “IMAGINiT’s Clarity Connect” tool, which supports an internally hosted collaboration solution.  Clarity is not cloud based and also offer’s valuable task automation and anywhere access to all of the data within a Revit Model, as well as the ability to edit the data in a Revit model via a mobile device.

We hope everyone will be able to attend and give your input on this interesting topic.

GBAUG Board

results.description:
One of the most striking and curious deities of the Aztec pantheon is Ehecatl, a duck-billed deity embodying ethereal concepts such as rain-bringing wind and the breath of life. In jarring contrast, Quetzalcoatl—a better-known Aztec deity who also embodies the same concepts of wind—is represented as a quetzal-plumed rattlesnake. Through epigraphic and iconographic studies of the Olmec, the Maya, and the cultures of Central Mexico, Karl Taube will trace the origin of Ehecatl in eastern Mesoamerica and its subsequent introduction into Central Mexico, highlighting its relevance and associations with Quetzalcoatl.

Free


Complimentary event parking available at the 52 Oxford Street Garage.
results.name: The Mythic and Cultural Origins of a Mesoamerican Wind God: A Lecture

results.description:
This meeting is sponsored by Akamai. 
Thanks to Mark Knowlton for coordinating the space, food and the drinks.

Java and JVM: Developing Android Apps with Kotlin

Kotlin is a new language that compiles to JVM bytecode (or JavaScript). Although only in beta release at time of writing, an official 1.0 Beta has been announced. Kotlin has many characteristics that make it very compelling for use in Android app development, including Interoperability with Java, Lambdas, Null Safety, Extension Methods, Data Classes, relatively small size and method count, top notch support in Android Studio, and others.

In this class, we will provide not only an introduction to Kotlin, but also cover the use of Kotlin in Android app development, such as using the Kotlin Extensions for Android plugin which provides some similar functionalities as the Butterknife library. We will also illustrate the basic use of Kotlin with other popular Android libraries, such as Dagger 2, Retrofit 2 and RxJava/RxAndroid.

The aim is not only to introduce the syntax of Kotlin and the advantages they allow, but also to highlight some useful common idioms afforded by the language, and to provide context by showing the use of the language with some popular open-source libraries commonly used by Android developers. We will use actual code snippets from a no-frills but functional demo Android app to clarify the concepts and material we introduce in the class.

Presenter 

C.L. Kim is in software engineering with the mobile ad platform Infrastructure/FastPath team at Millennial Media, part of AOL. The team is charged with architecting and building out the infrastructure and subsystems to support real-time processing of events at high QPS rate, with high reliability, and at scale. C.L. has an MBA and MSE in Computer and Information Science from the University of Pennsylvania, and is developer of a fun Android app. He taught for a number of years the IEEE Boston Section's continuing education class on Introduction to Android Application Framework and APIs.
results.name: Java and JVM: Developing Android Apps with Kotlin

Although we start around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
We're excited to host an intimate talk with Diane Hessan, CEO at Startup Institute, about discovering your true passion and how to turn it into a meaningful career. Diane's bio and the description of her session are below. We hope you'll join us!

Diane will discuss how to develop your short- and long-term strategic thinking from assessing your current position, identifying new opportunities, the importance of culture fit, and how to connect with the right mentors. Diane is also sure to make you laugh as she shares stories and tips from her own personal experience.

Diane Hessan is a successful entrepreneur, marketer and author. She has spent her career as a business executive, and as co-author of the book Customer-Centered Growth: Five Strategies for Building Competitive Advantage. She is also Chairman of Communispace, where she was CEO for 13 years. Diane has been awarded the Pinnacle Award from the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce, the Most Admired CEO award from the Boston Business Journal, Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year, and third on The Boston Globe's Top Women in Technology List. She received her M.B.A. from Harvard Business School and her B.A. in Economics from Tufts University. She has two grown daughters, and is also founder of The Sound Bytes, an a cappella group that sings about business.



Schedule


Doors open at 6:15pm; if you arrive before 6:15pm, please wait in the 1st floor lobby, as no one will be available to let you in upstairs. We encourage you to arrive by 6:30pm to get a good seat and meet other attendees. The program will begin promptly at 6:45pm.

Location

14th Floor, Room Charles

Cambridge Innovation Center

1 Broadway


Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall/MIT

Metered street parking is available (but limited) on Broadway St., Third St., and Main St.

Access

Please bring photo ID. Upon entering 1 Broadway you'll check in with security. Tell them you're here for the Women's Coding Collective event on the 14th floor.

Once you depart the elevator, you'll find glass doors that are locked. Look for the door sign for access info.

We're meeting in the room labeled Charles.
results.name: Building A Career You Love with Diane Hessan (free event)

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.

results.description:
Tonight we're going to be building and tinkering with 3 autonomous robots, getting them ready to compete.


We'll have three teams each working on a 2 wheeled robot, building them, programming them, and setting them free.

If we have time we'll get them to compete in various challenges.

---------------

Also tonight, our regular project night:

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

Find us: http://p.irateship.com/treasuremap.html

results.description:
Wellness Workshop 


Wellness means the healthy balance of the mind, body and spirit that results in an overall feeling of well-being.  

How well do you feel overall? Are you interested in having more energy, vitality and peace in your life?  

In this short workshop, you will get exposure to a number of new methods being used in alternative and complementary medicine to help aid in overall health, including:


• NAET -- Elimination of Allergies

• Neuro-Emotional Techniques

• Acupuncture

 • Self-care techniques to immediately address stress in your body

Terry Plante is a Licensed Acupuncturist and a Registered Pharmacist. She holds a Master’s Degree in Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine from New England School of Acupuncture. She is licensed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Board of Registration in Medicine.  Terry specializes in an Allergy Recovery Program and an Emotional Release Technique. She is dedicated to helping people live a physically thriving, emotionally balanced, and spiritually connected life.  Terry has successfully used acupuncture/acupressure, and various stress reduction techniques to help hundreds of patients with a variety of acute and chronic physical and emotional health conditions.
results.how_to_find_us: We are found in the former Parker Elementary School. Free parking lot on the side of the building
results.name: Healing Roots: Workshop on Wellness

results.description:
Speaker: Nicolas Vidal-Naquet, Veterinarian, Beekeeper, Author, NY Bee Sanctuary board member, visiting from France on book tour, author talk at 7:00 pm.

Nicolas Vidal-Naquet DVM, graduated in apiculture and honeybee medicine, and is a veterinary practitioner and lecturer in honeybee biology at the Veterinary School of Alfort, France. His recently published textbook, “Honeybee Veterinary Medicine”, while written for veterinarians in the emerging field of apiculture science, can also be beneficial to beekeepers, animal health and environmental agencies. 


Dr. Vidal-Naquet’s book provides an overview of bee biology, the bee in the wider environment, intoxication, bee diseases, bee parasites (with a large part dedicated to the mite Varroa Destructor) pests, enemies and veterinary treatment and actions relating to honeybee health. The book also covers current topics such as climate change, crop pollination, use of phytosanitary products, antibiotic resistance and Colony Collapse.


Cheese and French honey [from Nicolas!] to be paired.
results.name: November BABA Meeting & Book Talk

Location:
G2 Technology Group Inc.
320 Congress St. 2nd Floor, Boston, MA 02210
www.g2techgroup.com[masked] x729
Contact: Glenn Grant, CEO.

Parking:
There are three nearby parking lots within convenient walking distance of 320 Congress Street.
1.  LAZ Parking lot, uncovered, 321 Congress Street, directly across the street
2.  Farnsworth Street Garage, multi level garage, 17 Farnsworth Street (right around the corner)
3.  Congress Street/Farnsworth Street Lot (uncovered) one block down Congress Street


Sponsors:
• Space, logistics & coordination – G2 Technology Group
• Food and Beverage – Ansible, LogicMonitor & Sumo Logic

Amenities:
·  Cool raffle prizes from G2 including a Hoverboard
·  Swag giveaways from sponsors
·  Plenty of food and beverage, bring your appetite!
·  Great networking opportunity with the Boston AWS user community


Presentation: Leveraging DevOps to Kick Start CI/CD at Your Startup

A double header presentation by:
Glenn Grant - CEO & Chief Visionary
Kiril Dubrovsky - Senior Solutions Architect
G2 Technology Group Inc.

Abstract:
Continuous Integration and Delivery approaches to software development are unquestionably the way to go, but how do you get there with limited resources, time and budget?

In this presentation we’ll walk through a basic CI/CD pipeline built on AWS and discuss where you can plug in open source, commercial and native AWS tools. As we walk down the path to deployment we’ll review some popular tools DevOps teams are leveraging to automate and manage the process of building, testing and deploying code faster than ever before. We’ll discuss how you can manage your infrastructure as code and provide developers the tools they need to embrace DevOps with open arms. Your company will be better positioned to get new features to market more quickly and decrease the time taken to respond to issues, all with tools that are already at your fingertips in the AWS console. Glenn will talk about the conceptual overview and business benefits, followed by Kiril’s technical demo of these tools in action.


Presentation: 5 Years Of Building SaaS On AWS - A Story By Sumo Logic

Christian Beedgen – Co-Founder & CTO, Sumo Logic

Abstract:
SaaS architectures can be deployed onto AWS in a number of ways, and each optimizes for different factors from security to cost optimization. Come learn more about common deployment models used on AWS for SaaS architectures and how each of those models are tuned for customer specific needs. We will also review options and tradeoffs for common SaaS architectures, including cost optimization, resource optimization, performance optimization, and security and data isolation.

Christian Bio: Christian is the Co-Founder and CTO of Sumo Logic, Inc, and has spent the past 15 years architecting enterprise software and leading development teams. Prior to co-founding Sumo Logic, Christian served as Chief Architect at ArcSight, where he designed and implemented the core backend event handling and object-relational mapping frameworks and helped in the design and development of a flexible framework for real-time query processing.
