results.description:
**Please note, the Harvard Film Archive is cash-only. Admission to this event is $12.**
Guy Maddin's surreal Canadian vision is truly singular in a crowded avant-garde field. The Film Archive claims he will be there in person for his showing of My Winnipeg. I'll let the HFA describe the film, as I haven't seen it and I wouldn't even venture to describe the films of his that I have seen:


Found footage, Super 8 and shoddy digital video collide in My Winnipeg, a film made for Canada's Documentary Channel that has little-to-no interest in a straightforward presentation of factual information. Narrated like esoteric beat poetry throughout by Maddin himself, the film creates a potent dream space that reflects on his upbringing in Manitoba's cold, dreary capital through a funhouse collage of styles recycled from the kind of late-night television Maddin ingested as a child while staving off subzero temperatures. Rites of passage at the local hockey arena, sitcoms of domestic dissatisfaction, surreal accounts of Winnipegian rituals and festivities, reflections on the quasi-maternal geography of the city with its winding rivers and shadowy alleyways—all are folded into the dense sprawl of My Winnipeg, which takes larger form as Maddin’s alleged attempt to “film his way out” of the city. Cinematic autobiographies do not get more eccentric or singular than this.
Preceded by: Nude Caboose: An extremely happy shirtless man attempts, and succeeds, in getting the party started as he leads a group of dancers in a joyful caboose frolic.
Spanky: To the Pier and Back: Inspired by the stories of W.G. Sebald and Oskar Fischinger’s film Walking From Munich to Berlin, Maddin takes his then-girlfriend’s dog Spanky (co-star in My Winnipeg) out to the pier in what turns out to be their last walk together in this endearing portrait.
results.name: My Winnipeg with Guy Maddin in person, Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
A beautiful soul passed recently, Dr. Wayne Dyer, renowned as “The Father of Motivation.” His inspiring books and messages had helped millions, leaving one with a sense of awe, wonder, and undying curiosity to live life to the fullest. 

Let’s celebrate and appreciate Dr Dyer by watching The Shift (movie), a compelling portrait of three modern lives in need of new direction and new meaning, when we long to find the purpose that is our unique contribution to the world. 

The film invites us to explore the powerful shift from the ego constructs we are taught early in life by parents and society—which promote an emphasis on achievement and accumulation—are shown in contrast to a life of meaning, focused on serving and giving back.

After watching the movie, we’ll be discussing 

• what the movie may have inspired you to make a shift in and

• your next bold step to attract a more meaningful life in 2016

***************************************************

RSVP "YES" ONLY if you know you're coming. 

We'll be providing snacks & refreshments. So, to keep "green" & cost down, please RSVP "Yes" only when you can honor your commitment & show up. Many of you have been wonderful with this & we very much appreciate your support! 

****************************************************** 

For parking & directions (via T or driving) info to Dave's loft : 

(1) Go here: http://www.meetup.com/lawofattraction-us/files/ 

(2) Log in 

(3) Scroll down and open file "Directions & Parking_BostonLOA Meetup"
results.name: Discover The Shift to Attract a More Meaningful Life

results.description:
My Winnipeg

Directed by Guy Maddin. With Darcy Fehr, Ann Savage, Louis Negin
Canada 2007, 35mm, color & b/w, 80 min

Found footage, Super 8 and shoddy digital video collide in My Winnipeg, a film made for Canada's Documentary Channel that has little-to-no interest in a straightforward presentation of factual information. Narrated like esoteric beat poetry throughout by Maddin himself, the film creates a potent dream space that reflects on his upbringing in Manitoba's cold, dreary capital through a funhouse collage of styles recycled from the kind of late-night television Maddin ingested as a child while staving off subzero temperatures. Rites of passage at the local hockey arena, sitcoms of domestic dissatisfaction, surreal accounts of Winnipegian rituals and festivities, reflections on the quasi-maternal geography of the city with its winding rivers and shadowy alleyways—all are folded into the dense sprawl of My Winnipeg, which takes larger form as Maddin’s alleged attempt to “film his way out” of the city. Cinematic autobiographies do not get more eccentric or singular than this.

Preceded by

Nude Caboose

Directed by Guy Maddin. With Darren Anderson, Jim Bell, Mike Bell
Canada 2006, digital video, color, 3 min

An extremely happy shirtless man attempts, and succeeds, in getting the party started as he leads a group of dancers in a joyful caboose frolic.

Spanky: To the Pier and Back

Directed by Guy Maddin. With Spanky
Canada 2008, video, b/w, 4 min

Inspired by the stories of W.G. Sebald and Oskar Fischinger’s film Walking From Munich to Berlin, Maddin takes his then-girlfriend’s dog Spanky (co-star in My Winnipeg) out to the pier in what turns out to be their last walk together in this endearing portrait.

See you at the movies,

John

results.description:
You've seen the invitations to doorknock, and some of you have participated.  Now it's time to celebrate the efforts!

***Note: this is a potluck!  See details below for more.***


From the Facebook event:

Over the past 5 months, Boston Doorknockers has brought together over 100 mostly white and non-Black POC together to go out into white neighborhoods to talk about #blacklivesmatter, racial justice, the need for principled resistance like the Somerville 18 and for police accountability and transparency through Boston Police Camera Action Team.

Join us on 11/13 for community celebration, reflection, evaluation, and appreciation - we'll have a SHORT programme, food, and merriment. We'll also talk a little about where we can go from here, and how to keep the work moving forward this winter.

POTLUCK: please bring a dish, snack, dessert, or non-alcoholic beverage to share and label for common allergens (nuts, dairy, gluten, shellfish, etc)/dietary needs.

As always, children are welcome at our events. We will have child care available and kids are welcome to join in the fun.
results.name: Doorknockers End of Season Community Bash & Potluck!

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the building.  The stairs will bring you to the door.
results.name: (Newton) Intermediate Longsword, Dagger and Grappling

TGIF South Shore Billiards/Pool Social!!

Friday, November 13th @ 7:30-9:30pm

O'Lindy's

170 Quincy Avenue (Route 53 SB)

Quincy, MA 02169

Phone #[masked]

Website: http://olindysbowling.com/

Meeting Location:  Please meet near the front desk.  If you arrive after we head to our pool tables look for a meetup sign.  The reservation is under "Angela" and "Meetup."

Host/Organizer: Angela and Jodi (Reservation is under Meetup and Angela.)

Min/Max: Minimum of 6 people 48 hours prior to the event.  Maximum of 25 total attendees.

Guests: 1 Adult (21+) per Member
Cash Only Policy: Please bring cash! Paying for our meals in cash allows us to avoid the confusion of having the waitstaff run multiple credit card slips and generally helps to keep things simpler for everyone.


Cost/Fees: Each pool table is $12/hr w/ a $10 deposit.  We will be collecting $5pp to cover the cost of pool and appetizers/snacks that we will order and/or bring.  (Please note, we rarely collect event fees but we do need to pay for pool and some snacks may add to the fun of the evening.)  If you want to make your annual $10 voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio and it will cover your cost for tonight's event.  Biagio requests a $10 donation after attending your 3rd event.  (If half the people who attended 3+ events actually made the donation it would be a one-time request.  Alas, not so.)

RSVP Deadline: Friday, November 13th @ 2pm ~ Any changes made after this time will be considered a No-Show.

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: TBD

No-Show Policy:  People who RSVP "Yes" to events are expected to exercise common sense and common courtesy. That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events.  Please be advised that any Assistant Organizer (AO) or the Group Organizer (GO) can remove a member from Social Fun who has 3 No-Shows in the past 3 months.  Additionally, Organizers may disallow members with 2 or more "No Show" marks from attending their events.  *Please keep in mind that we are reserving pool tables based on the number of people who RSVP Yes to attend and if we show-up missing more than 10% of the people it has an adverse affect on everyone else attending as well as the venue as we are planning based on RSVPs and if there's a Waitlist (WL) then you are taking away a spot for someone else if you do not change your RSVP when you are no longer able to attend.*

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Parking: Free parking on-site and in their extended lot across the street.  If lots are full drive north on Route 53 to the next set of lights where you will take a right (onto Scammell Street) and then you can take a left into the big free parking lot where Quincy Credit Union and a gym are located.  (Please do not park in the strip mall or Citizens Bank parking lots.)

Directions/Location Overview:  This is located on Route 53 NB in Quincy about 2 miles from the Braintree line and less than 1/2 mile from Kam Man Plaza (where Bradlees used to be over 2 decades ago).  This is also on the bus line which you can catch from the Quincy Center T station.  For exact directions, please go to their website or google map it.

results.description:
Dance with us from 7:45 pm - 11:30 at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.

The fabulous, fun-filled event begins with a class from 7:45 to 9:15 and continues with dj'd dancing until  11pm music provided by some extraordinary DJs.

11-13 Class Suzy Spivey – JourneyDance™

Get out of your mind and into your body.  Access your innate joy, awaken your passionate heart, and celebrate your Human Spirit!  This conscious movement flow uses guided imagery, freestyle movement exploration, shamanic rituals, and evocative music to lead you on an empowering journey towards freedom, aliveness, and physical and emotional transformation.  Your mind becomes clear, free, and positive, allowing you to access your inner power and passionate heart. Bring your willingness to play, explore, and be open to joyful connection—with yourself and others. 

Suzy Spivey has been teaching JourneyDance™ classes and workshops since 2006. She serves as Seasonal Staff at the Omega Institute and is a Certified Journey Dance, Kripalu Yoga Dance, and Shake Your Soul teacher. She is also a Certified Coach and Success Strategist, specializing in guiding people through transition to transformation. Visit suzyspivey.com for more information. 

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 7:45 pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:15, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

results.description:
The Jaycee walking club!
I am extending you this invite to get you moving!
We meet Saturday mornings, 7:45 am, Fruit Street Mansfield, WW II Veterans Memorial Trail (Bike Path). Just past the airport. We go for just about a 4 mile walk, takes a little over an hour, and we have lots of fun. If you can’t do the 4 miles come and do what you can and work your way up. We usually have enough people to split up into sub-groups of leisure walkers and speedsters.

I use Map My Walk to keep track of our time and distance. This is a free app that you can download to your smartphone, should you want to start keeping track of your exercise, minutes and calories burned. It has a lot of features that I am sure you would have fun with.

If you can, let me know if you will be walking with us, so we don’t start without you. If we are all gathered before 8 we tend to just get going at that point.

If you are interested in joining our walking club, either this time or sometime in the future, please let me know and I will include you on that email list.
Laureen House [masked]
results.name: Foxboro Jaycees Walking Club

results.description:
Organizers: Steve Blum @[masked] and Paul-William @[masked]


=========================

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event. Sometimes the questions won't show up if you use a phone or tablet to RSVP so use a computer. 

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself as well as others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate. Contact me if you have any questions. .

=========================

What We're Doing...

Our plan is hike to the summit of the Mt. Nancy (3926') by way of the Nancy Pond Trail. En route, we will pass the spectacular Nancy Cascades and the upland ponds of Nancy and Norcross. We are also treated to a fine, wide view of the Pemigewasset Wilderness. The final ascent to the summit is not an official trail, so you won't find it on the maps. No car spotting will be necessary since we will summit the mountain and return the same way to our vehicles.


Since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety you will need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards. Use this link for more information about the summits and trails:

•http://trailsnh.com/URL/71394</a>


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.45092498117387&lat=44.088181468936426#.Vizohyt2GSo

Guests are not permitted - all participants must be members of the group.


Dogs are permitted - Dogs will only be permitted after contacting and with the prior approval of the event organizers.


Trip Summary...

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip, we will hike about 10 miles and climb just over 3300 feet. It should take an average hiker nearly 7 hours to complete this trip. This event is considered to be INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain, although the final 0.7 miles to Mt. Nancy is very steep (806' with occasionally poor footing).


We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you. 


What to Bring...

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:

• <a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Remember that it is WINTER IN THE WHITES! Light traction will be MANDATORY.  (Micospikes or Hillsounds) Headlamps with a set of spare, lithium batteries are MANDATORY. Review the file attached above, but be sure to include full winter clothing and lighter fall layers, full raingear, warm hats, insulated mittens, a fleece jacket, balaclava or face mask, emergency shelter, first aid kit, and plenty of food and water for a full day of hiking.  ABSOLUTELY NO COTTON CLOTHES! Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Directions...


We will meet in the parking lot at the trail head for the Nancy Pond Trail which is located on the west side of Route 302 about 5 miles West of Bartlett Village and 17 miles East of Twin Mountain, Rt. 3/302.  According to Google Maps this meeting spot is about 170 miles from Boston and it should take about 3 hours and  to drive there. We won't cancel this or a modified trip due to weather conditions until the day before, since we all know how accurate forecasts can be!  We will email you a couple of days prior to inform you of any final details, and of course, if we have to change any plans due to conditions.


Use this link for customizable driving directions:

•https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Boston,+Massachusetts/44.1123973,-71.3537231/@44.1069814,-71.3829736,14z/data=!4m9!4m8!1m5!1m1!1s0x89e3652d0d3d311b:0x787cbf240162e8a0!2m2!1d-71.0588801!2d42.3600825!1m0!3...


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: FOUR ASPECTS OF NANCY: THE BROOK, CASCADE, POND AND THE MOUNTAIN

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

DIVORCE MATTERS FOR YOU! - WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT DIVORCE IN MA.

This half-day workshop on taking the next step to untying the knot covers the legal, financial, family and personal issues that are often encountered during the divorce process.

Trained divorce professionals will provide you with the knowledge and information you need to make informed decisions in your divorce.  Take back control of your life and  empower your way through the process with confidence and peace of mind.

First workshop starts on Saturday, September 13th and continues the second Saturday of every other month - next workshop November 14th.

Cost: $25  

Register and pay online at www.TheDivorceCenter.org

results.description:
Join the guides of the LLBean Dedham store while we hike to the Moose Hill Bluffs. These open cliffs offer an expansive southeast view, with Gillette Stadium in the distance. On the way, we'll cross several streams, tapped maple trees and a "bat barn".

If you are not a Massachusetts Audubon member, there is a $4 fee.  If you are a member, it's free.

ACTIVITY LEVEL: Easy.

WHERE TO MEET: In the parking lot of the Audubon Sanctuary.

WHAT TO BRING: Weather-appropriate clothing, hiking boots, sunglasses, enough water for 2 hours, bug spray.

OPTIONAL RECOMMENDED ITEMS: Sunglasses, binoculars, cameras, snacks.

Sign up at LLBean.com/Dedham find this event and fill out the online waiver.
results.name: Hike the Bluffs at Moose Hill Audubon Sanctuary

results.description:
Global Day of Code Retreat is a worldwide coordinated celebration of our software craft. (http://gdcr.coderetreat.org/)

Come join us for multiple rounds of solving Conway's Game of Life with different constraints. It's a great time to meet and hone your craft with like minded professionals. Breakfast and lunch will be provided.

Expect test-driven pair programming in a language you and your pairs like. Bring a laptop with your favorite programming environments installed.


Sponsored and hosted by Zipcar.

You may be able to find street parking, but watch out for reserved spaces. There are parking garages on both Stillings and Farnsworth (one block each side of Thomson Pl) that are reasonably priced for the city.
results.name: Global Day of Code Retreat 2015 - Boston, MA

Meet to paint the model for a four week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $65.    Three hours each Saturday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $55 or $65 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
The Japanese Flower Arranging,  "Ikenobo Ikebana Society of Boston" ,  invites you to learn the principles of the Ikenobo-style. 


The Ikenobo Workshop is from 9:30am--2:30pm. You will make 2 lovely arrangements and have Lunch.

Ikenobo is the oldest and original style of Japanese Flower Arranging which began with Buddhist priests in Japan. 

***Please Note: In order to attend this Workshop, you need to bring various items.  If you do not have the items---please contact Mimi Santini-Ritt at: [masked] (Perhaps she can allow you to buy/borrow the necessary items). 

***You must also Pre-Pay to Mimi Santori-Ritt. (see address below)

Please Bring: 

a "shoka" container (for example, see illustration), kenzan (pinholder), scissors/garden shears, small bucket, and a bag for trash. 

Bring your own lunch, refreshments will be served.

Send check in the amount of $40 (includes floral material for two arrangements), by November 4, to

Mimi Santini-Ritt (92 Grant Avenue, Newton MA 02459; [masked]), please include your email and phone information

Mimi Santini-Ritt Tel:[masked]

results.description:
NB: this is not a WCC event, but we've heard from members that it'd be nice to connect with friends to go to outside events, so here you go. Use the comments below to coordinate with Marcela and other attendees. =)

From the Hack4Fem event description:

The Hack4Fem (#Hack4Fem) hackathon is an event where participants and activists discuss feminist causes, and then brainstorm and engineer solutions in a positive and creative environment.

We aim to expose problems and challenges that activists face on a regular basis and explore how technology can help make their efforts easier. The goal is to use technology to support feminist activism.


The event will feature the following speakers:

• Kelley Marie Adams, Program Manager, MIT Violence Prevention and Response
• Vienna Rothberg, Program Manager for PLEASURE (Peers Leading Education About Sexuality and Speaking up for Relationship Empowerment)
• Dr. Jyoti Sinha, Visiting Scholar, Women's and Gender Studies Department, UMass Boston
• Kate Carson, Boston Doula Project

If you're going to this event, please RSVP here so Marcela will know to be on the lookout for you, but please also remember to RSVP to the event on Eventbrite: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hack4fem-hackathon-tickets-18967474226
results.how_to_find_us: https://whereis.mit.edu/?go=E17
results.name: En Masse: Hack4Fem Hackathon (free event)

results.description:
Portrait Weekend  Sat 14 and Sun 15 Nov 


A whole weekend of unique instruction in portraiture with a wonderful opportunity to add to your portfolio. Working in a very small group of just six participants we will spend two days from 10am until 4pm improving our portraiture skills.

Over this two day class we will have three different models to shoot and we will cover a wide selection of lighting and portrait styles. All models will sign a release giving you the rights to use the images you take.

All lighting and equipment will be provided, you just need to bring your camera, batteries and media cards.

The class will take place in the studio and on location (weather permitting) close to the studio.  You will learn how to create:

stunning natural light portraits;

Simple indoor portraits using a speeedlight; 

Studio portraits using a variety of set-ups

Simple and  effective posing for  individuals, groups and couples. 

The cost for two full days of instruction and shooting is just $425

Check out some of the images from our previous portrait class at:

http://www.meetup.com/Photoworks/photos/4812242/

It is a great way to spend a fall weekend while obtaining valuable instruction from a true professional and gaining some stunning images for your portfolio.

Recent attendees in Ian’s portraiture classes have commented:

“"Fantastic course! I went from taking iphone looking shots to near-professional stuff...Ian is a great teacher, very patient and very generous"  Walt

“Useful and practical information packed into the well thought out agenda.”  Jean

"Lots of very eye-opening information. I came to the workshop with a list of questions and Ian answered all of them without me having to ask. Thanks, Ian, for generously sharing what you've learned in your business experience"..  Denise

"This masterclass with Ian was worth every cent and time invested. Ian covered all the basic portrait lighting techniques, gears and set up but more importantly, the ins and outs of running a successful portrait business. In this increasingly competitive market, where every Joe, Bob and Mary with a DSLR claims to be a professional, it is rare to find a true seasoned professional that is so genuinely interested in sharing all the secrets of the trade that he has amassed during his thirty plus years of photography".  Donald "great introduction to studio lighting techniques and how to take a head shot. As usual, Ian added a bonus by providing us a cliff notes course on business psychology 101 for the emerging pro photographer as well as sharing his experiences as a working photographer-- all very enlightening. Would recommend this class to anyone thinking about getting nto photography as a full time business". Alfred

results.description:
TRANQUIL ABIDING DAY RETREAT

SATURDAY | NOV. 14th 


10:00am - 4:00pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Mar York

Take your meditation practice to the next level in this day-long retreat on the nature of your own mind. 

This sublime and relaxing meditation on the clear nature of the mind gives us deep insight into its flexible and limitless nature. In turn, this helps us to understand through our own experience methods to actualize our potential for lasting happiness and peace. We will be taught a special method for accessing a more subtle level of awareness that will greatly empower our ability to meditate as well as to experience more freedom and joy in our daily life.  If you have been looking to deepen your experience of meditation, then this retreat is for you!


Everyone welcome - no experience necessary! 

Workshop will consist of 4 sessions with an hour long lunch break in the middle. Light snacks provided.

Cost | $35  / $20 students & seniors.   Free for Patrons!

Please click here to register.  Seating is limited!

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.

results.description:
We'll run from the cafe to the river path, go west to Prospect Street, and double back along the river. Finishing up with one loop around the common to make it an even 2 miles. Since it's an out and back we can spread out at different paces to accommodate beginner to advanced runners, but still start and finish together.  Coffee/goodies at the cafe afterwards is also optional but highly recommended :-).

This is a great way to get into running, introduce your friends to the group, or just start your Saturday on a high note.  All ages and levels welcome.

If you are hesitating to come, keep in mind that nearly every week we have beginning runners who use a run/walk/run technique.  If you take walk breaks you will probably not be alone, and it's the best way to get into running, so come on out!

results.description:
Join us as we explore the Town of Lincoln's Conservation Land via its extensive trail system.  


On this 10 mile loop we’ll visit Walden Pond, Adams Woods, pass through farmland, the grounds of the Codman Estate, Codman Communty Farm, the grounds of the Gropius House, and the Decordova Museum Sculpture Park.

Expect to spend up to a minimum of five hours on this trek; it could take longer.

Level:  easy/moderate for distance, with elevation gain of 500'.


There's an $8 fee per car to park at Walden.


Carpooling is recommended.  To arrange for carpooling post the request under the Comments section but make the arrangements via the Messenger.  Click on any member's profile page, then click on 'message'.

Dogs are not welcome on BSOT events, nor are guests.  If you would like to bring a non-member they must first apply to become a member.  Then, if they are approved,  they then must RSVP YES.  No exceptions.  Please observe these rules. 

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events. 

I will send out an email the day before the event with the weather forecast, last minute reminders, etc. 

Extreme weather conditions cancel this event.

The guest list is limited to 24.  Join the wait-list as spots often do become available.

http://lincolnconservation.org


http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-north/walden-pond-state-reservation.html


http://www.historicnewengland.org/historic-properties/homes/codman-estate


http://www.decordova.org/


The Fine Print:


Duration: Approximately 5 hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day.

The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

I will find out the trail conditions the day before and then send them to all who have RSVPd yes via an email. But, use your own judgment.

Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

This hike is rated Easy/Moderate. You should be able to stay with the group. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree (woof!). If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below:

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.
results.name: Lincoln Conservation Land Trek

results.description:
This will be a workout on this Moderate Blue Hills hike, it will not be a fast paced hike, but it will be long, and lots of hills to climb for the first and last half of the hike. This hike is just about 8 miles long, we are doing a point to point hike on the skyline.


We are doing the other side, the not as popular side, of the Blue Hills skyline hike. There are many beautiful views on this side as well. The first hill we come on is Rattlesnake hill, elevation is 350'. We will then go over Wampatuck hill, Chickatawbut hill, and end up at Buckhill, elevation is 496 feet here, and we have very beautiful views of Boston,where we will have our lunch. Remember this is a meetup hike, we begin as a group and we end as a group. I am volunteering to lead this hike because I enjoy hiking in the woods, supporting each other, and showing the different trails that Blue Hills has to offer.

What to bring:

If you use trekking poles, I suggest bringing them, also be sure to have at least a liter of water, good hiking shoes or trail runners, please dress appropriately for the weather, remember layers always works. Bring your lunch, we will be having lunch on top of Buck Hill. The start time is 10:00 am, we will meet at Shea Rink, the end time is determined by the pace of our hikers, I allotted 5 hours , considering breaks and lunch.
I will be in the bright green Hyundai in the parking lot.
results.how_to_find_us: I will be in the bright green Hyundai in the parking lot.
results.name: Blue Hills Hike, from Shea Rink to Buck Hill, in Quincy Ma. 10- am til 3:00pm

results.description:
Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

• Anyone from the community can participate. 

• Led by experienced runners. 

• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 

• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 

• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

results.description:
Visit the only (so far) cohousing neighborhood in Boston proper, close to the T and the Jamaicaway bike route. Discover why people love living together in sustainable community, blending privacy and neighborly connections, your own kitchen with regular common meals. Meet cohousers young and old, tour the extensive Common House and yard, and map your path to community living. Learn about current and future openings to rent and buy in community.

https://sites.google.com/site/jpcohousinginternet/_/rsrc/1408642841004/config/customLogo.gif?revision=9

This tour repeats: the second Saturday at 2 PM, and the fourth Sunday at 10 AM. Be sure to check the date for the one you are RSVPing to.

About JP Cohousing

We are delighted to have you over to our virtual home! Cohousing is more than just a house-- it's a way of living that makes it easy for you to meet neighbors, make friends, find playmates for the kids, attend parties, or find a movie group. We are situated in the artistic Brookside area of the socially and environmentally-conscious neighborhood of Jamaica Plain in Boston.

In addition to individual fully-equipped units, cohousing members share and enjoy many large common areas because living in cohousing means valuing a sense of community. Our shared facilities include a huge dining hall where we host dinners, parties, and social events; a cozy living room where we show movies and host various clubs; a toddler room for young kids; a rumpus room with exercise equipment, ping-pong and a home theater; office space and meeting room; a laundry room; a large indoor bike storage area; and craft studios. Truly, living in cohousing offers the best of city living, bringing together a diverse and vibrant group of people who value individuality and a sense of community.


Learn more at www.jpcohousing.org

On the tradition of our winter in-door sites, let's sketch some interiors  at the Fogg Museum at Harvard Square!

(I'll take the opportunity to give you an update on our upcoming show exhibition. If you can't attend I will publish here in comments anyway after the meetup)

**Admission is $15 for adults, $10 for non-Harvard students, free for Cambridge residents and free for Massachusetts residents ON SATURDAYS 10am to 12PM. ***

The Fogg Museum is one of three Harvard Art Museums. It opened in 1895, and was notable for being the first art facility in North America tailored to the training of scholars and conservators. The Fogg's collection of Western painting, drawing and sculpture is extensive and renowned.

The Fogg was remodeled (By Renzo Piano Building Workshop, who also did the Gardner) and has just re-opened this past year.

http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/about/history-and-the-three-museums


Please note that the museum requires PENCILS ONLY for sketching in the facility.

Admission is $15 for adults, $10 for non-Harvard students, free for Cambridge residents and free for Massachusetts residents ON SATURDAYS 10am to 12PM. Other details can be found here:

http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/plan-your-visit


11pm: meet at the entry

11-1pm: explore and sketch

1pm: reconvene in the lobby to share work

as usual, please watch the comments for last-minute adjustments and questions.

results.description:
(a set of 4 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is four linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all four classes (Oct 24, 31, Nov. 7 and 14) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

results.description:
What is the ‘Internet of Cows?’ 


The Internet of Cows is an initiative led by BovControl to connect every cow on the planet to the cloud, with a result of improving data collection throughout the cattle production value chain, and thereby improving production and efficiency of the whole cattle industry.

What are we hacking?

The bottom line is that in order to increase efficiency and production, we need more data on cattle, cattle producers, and their land. Right now, data is primarily being collected by using pen and paper, and in some cases RFID technology and newer types of sensors. 

Unsurprisingly, these methods aren’t cutting it. The cattle industry is in dire need of a new sensor for cattle management…a new ‘wearable for cows.’ This, my friends, is what we are hacking. 

What kind of product requirements are we talking about?

The PR doc is a list that I would like to leave a bit open to foster creativity and imagination. However, I will say that the industry is concerned with animal health, early detection of illness and ovulation (heat), geo-location, and location. I will let you all brainstorm and will be happy to provide guidelines along the way. 

What is the goal of this hackathon?

BovControl will be hosting a larger ‘hackathon' with many of our industry partners in December. This event will focus on connecting the dots between existing technologies and new innovations both within and outside of the cattle industry. We will invite the most promising outputs and candidates from this November Internet of Cows hackathon to present a concept, design, or prototype to the December attendees with opportunity for development and partnership. 

Will we be building prototypes?

While the space at MassChallenge does in fact have a hardware lab, this hackathon will be focused on the concept and design of a new wearable for cattle. Each team will be provided with a Raspberry Pi, and participants are welcome to bring their own tools.  

Agenda: 

•  12p arrive and meet 

• 1p lunch & context of cattle industry

• 2p form teams & gun fires

• 6p Pizza 

• 9p "pencils down” 

• 9:30p judging

• 10:30 happy hour at Jerry Remy's Seaport
results.name: Hack wearables for... cows?

results.description:
Dr. Khosro Farhad is a neurologist specializing in peripheral nerve. He is affiliated with the Massachusetts General Hospital Nerve Unit. He provides medical care for patients with fibromyalgia, small fiber polyneuropathy (SFPN) and other neuromuscular disorders. For patients newly diagnosed with SFPN, potentially treatable causes can be sought from the patient’s medical history and blood tests. The MGH team is conducting research on treatment options. The research suggests that SFPN might possibly be linked to some cases of ME/CFS.

The program will also include an overview of Fibromyalgia from the clinical perspective: presentation, diagnosis and treatments. 

Presented by the Massachusetts CFIDS/ME & FM Association, www.masscfids.org

This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops.

Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. Please also install the IPython (http://ipython.org/install.html), Natural Language Processing Toolkit (http://www.nltk.org/install.html), the full SciPy stack (http://scipy.org/install.html), and SciKit Learn (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/install.html). If you have trouble with this, please still come to the session, but we have a STRONG preference for having this taken care of at home so that we can focus on learning new things.

Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover Cryptography and Computer Security, Spam (Junk Email) Detection, Data Visualization, and an introduction to Machine Learning. If possible, please email [masked] a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Feel free to also email any questions or concerns. Accommodations and modifications will be made to fit student interest and ability.

Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

results.description:
Association for India’s Development
MIT & Boston Chapters
present
Between Life and Execution
Troy Davis and the Hidden Face of Capital Punishment
Talk: Gautam Narula, Author, Remain Free

Saturday, November 14, 2015 (3-5pm)
MIT, Bld 1, Room 190 https://whereis.mit.edu/?go=1
77 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139
Event is free and open to the public.

When Troy Davis was executed in 2011, despite serious doubts about his guilt, he was the most well-known death row inmate in the world. Drawing upon his close friendship with Davis and years working on the case, Gautam Narula shows how Troy Davis exemplifies the dark, hidden aspects of the death penalty the public rarely sees: the ugly politics that determine who lives and who dies, the brutal conditions on death row, the emotional toll capital punishment takes on the condemned and their families, and the legal maneuvers that allow innocent people to be executed. Learn more: www.remainfree.com

About AID: www.aidboston.org | [masked]
results.name: Between Life and Execution Troy Davis and the Hidden Face of Capital Punishment

results.description:
Forecasts are indicating clear sky conditions for Saturday evening. If you haven't yet participated in an event, I'll give you throughout Friday to sign up. After that point in time, those who participated in last week's kick-off event can grab a slot. If you own a telescope and want to bring it along, I encourage you to do so. For bean counting purposes, let me know if you plan to bring a telescope so that I can adjust the RSVP numbers.


The Moon will be a pretty, thin crescent in the southwestern sky at the start of the event, and won't play a factor. This means that we'll again go after the sort of celestial sights that we observed last Sunday evening. There will be plenty of artificial satellites to observe. If we are lucky, perhaps we will catch sight of some shooting stars from the Taurid meteor shower.

Temperatures are expected to be in the low 40s, with a northwest breeze of about 10 mph. So, plan to bundle up and wear warm footwear in order to stay comfortable.

We'll wrap things up around 7PM, as I need to close the IRWS gates when we are done.

The directions to IRWS are at

http://www.meetup.com/North_Shore_Stargazer_Group/files/

Please review them, even if you know your way to IRWS. The last page describes how to locate where the telescope will be set up in the parking lot.


We will be setting up at the far end of the dirt parking lot. If you are bringing a telescope, park up at the far end. If not bringing a telescope, park a little further away from the area where the telescopes will be set up, for safety sake. I'll be there by 4:45. Just look for the dark green Toyota Camry with the kayak rack.

Weather update as of 11/14/15: Weather forecasts indicate clear skies, for the event. Temperatures will be around 40 degrees, with a northwest breeze at 10-12 mph, resulting in a wind chill around 31 degrees. Definitely try to dress in layers, and bring along a warm hat and gloves. As always, hiking boots work very well in these sort of conditions.
results.name: Star Party at IRWS

results.description:
FULL!

Come join us for our 2015 Search for the perfect wine to pair with your family's Thanksgving dinner!

Pairing wines with a traditional Thanksgiving dinner is difficult. There is simply too much variety on the table! Turkey offers two distinct meat experiences: white meat from the breast and dark meat from the leg with fattier taste and texture. And then there are the side-dishes--potatoes, turnips, cranberries, stuffing, pearl onions, sweet potatoes, etc. It's a complicated melange of flavors, textures, starches, proteins and vegetables. What should you serve to accompany all this? Join us to find something your palate prefers for the big meal.

COST

This event is FREE, and open to all members. You will choose the wines and provide the food (see details below).

POLICIES

Limited to 40 total including +1s; I will roll out in blocks of 10 to let everyone get a shot at attending. Everyone must be a member of BostonWine. RSVP to get on the wait list, but please don't RSVP unless you're sure that you can make it. Keep your RSVP up-to-date--this is going to be a very popular event!

NOTE: As part of the RSVP process you will be asked to accept the group's Policies and Disclaimer (use a new web browser window to see the About Us section of our group's home page). You must answer "Yes" in this event's RSVP to attend. (Note, apparently some versions of the Meetup mobile app don't display this question -- in that case, RSVP with your phone and then use a web browser later on to update your RSVP). 

WHAT TO BRING 

Attendees are asked to bring a wine from the list below and an appetizer portion to share that is reminiscent of holiday foods, i.e. Turkey, Cranberry, Pumpkin, Stuffing, Sweet Potato, etc..

Unlike previous years, we will open our wine selection to wines from around the world. To bring some focus to our efforts, however, we have restricted the tasting to 3 overall flights, one white, one red and one dessert. Each flight will showcase your favorite examples of particular varieties that the Jim's believe work best with traditional Thanksgiving fare. We will run the white and red flights in parallel to accommodate those that have a white vs red preference.

Since its such a special holiday, we've increased our usual price range to: $15-$40.

The secret to successfully pairing a wine with Thanksgiving food is ACID.  A wine with balanced acidity can handle sweet, fat, acidic, salty, and starchy foods.

Here are the flights

White Wine Flight
With white wines the pairing priority is finding a wine with well-balanced acidity.

• Flight w1: Sparkling white or rose

• Flight w2: Sauvignon Blanc

• Flight w3: Alsace (Riesling, Gewurztraminer)

• Flight w4: Viognier 

Red Wine Flight
Red wines we are looking for balanced tanins

• Flight r1: Pinot Noir

• Flight r2: Beaujolais Crus (Morgon, Fleurie, Bouilly, Moulin-à-Vent, etc.)  

• Flight r3: Shirah/z

• Flight r4: Zinfandel 

Dessert Wine Flight
Focus here is on fortified wines like Sherry, Port, or high sugar wines etc.

• Flight d1: Oloroso Sherry

• Flight d2: Tawny Port

• Flight d3: late harvest Riesling

It would be great if we could get several bottles of the some of these wines, so please post your choices ASAP. If the above lineup proves too restrictive for someone (!?), then bring a wildcard. :-)

WHERE

The event will be held in the Club Room of Jim's apartment building in Cambridge (see address above--members only) 

We will have access to a demonstration kitchen, fridge, ice.

T: Alewife (Red line)

Parking: Guest parking not available at venue. Public transportation or a car service such as Uber is preferable. Otherwise, park at Alewife T station ($7). Park and walk to main lobby of apartment building and follow general directions. 

DRESS

Casual

ABOUT

The Hanover is a new luxury apartment building complex in Cambridge. It has a spacious club room where we'll be meeting, a spa-like pool, fitness center, pool, courtyard with fire pits, grills, high-end finishes, etc. Expect to see many more BostonWine events here!

For those interested in seeing a model apartment, leasing staff will be on hand before the event to do a tour (call ahead to be sure to get a spot). Remember to let them know that you're part of BostonWine. ;-) 

My thanks to Jim Smith for helping pull together this event.

-jim & jim
results.name: Search for the Perfect Thanksgiving Wine 2015!!

Michael Keaton, Mark Ruffalo, Rachel McAdams, Liev Schreiber, Brian d’Arcy James and Stanley Tucci star in Spotlight, the riveting true story of the Pulitzer Prize-winning Boston Globe investigation that would rock the city and cause a crisis in one of the world’s oldest and most trusted institutions. When the newspaper’s tenacious “Spotlight” team of reporters delve into allegations of abuse in the Catholic Church, their year-long investigation uncovers a decades-long cover-up at the highest levels of Boston's religious, legal and government establishment, touching off a wave of revelations around the world. Directed by Tom McCarthy (The Visitor, The Station Agent), Spotlight is a tense investigative thriller, tracing the steps to one of the biggest crime stories in modern times.

results.description:
We will meet for a short photo shoot after this year's CLICK! conference, where Jürgen will give a couple of presentations. We will explore Ned's Point lighthouse, one of the Cape Cod lights that we haven't explored before. This is a chance to document another active lighthouse and capture it with cloud streaks, stars or startrails.


The CLICK conference will be over at 4:30, we will meet at 5 at the above coordinates. Sunset is 4:23, nautical twilight with beautiful blue skies and some orange afterglow left begins just before 5, the night starts at 6.


Some impressions courtesy of various Flickr users:


The Milky Way comes up straight overhead from NE to SW, but the core is below the horizon at this time of year. We will have a 10% waxing crescent moon close to setting in the west at 7 pm, hence, not much light from that. Weather forecast predicts 15-20% cloud cover for good streaks and perhaps starry skies, but also quite windy at 13 mph and gusts to 28 mph. Tie down your intervalometer and camera strap! Temperatures will be around 40F, so dress warmly in layers, bring gloves, a head cover and hot fluids.


We will meet for dinner after the photo shoot at the Inn on Shipyard Park. Please add a comment if you are joining us for that (no comment if not).

results.description:
Reflect on what is good about your family, and put it into words.

What is a Happiness Gathering?

Happiness Gatherings are opportunities to put love and gratitude into action, in a fun, safe environment. An interactive discussion of the evening's topic is followed by an opportunity to actually DO some of those feel-good things that you may not get around to on your own.

This Evening's Topic: Finding the Good in Your Family

All families (like all people!) are mixture of great love and great imperfection.  Focusing on what you admire and appreciate about your family members doesn't make their imperfections go away, but it does make it more likely that you will enjoy their company -- and that they will enjoy yours.

At this event, we'll talk a little about the nature of families, then create word clouds that represent our families' unique strengths. (Feel free to define family as broadly or narrowly as you want, and include only the people you want to include.)

Dinner is potluck style, so please bring a dish to pass -- or if you don't have time to cook or get to the store, just donate some money to cover drinks and paper goods.

Admission is free; Donations accepted with gratitude

About the Facilitator

Anne Lafleur, MSW, is a speaker, facilitator, and coach specializing in happiness and human connection. She helps individuals and groups identify small gifts that would feel good to give, and practice giving them away unconditionally. More information is on her website, www.thegiftofhappiness.org.
results.name: Happiness Gathering: Family Appreciation Potluck

Live in the Metrowest area and want to come to our events but they're too far away?  Want to make some new friends, eat some good food and play some fun games in the process?   Make some time on your calendar for Saturday night because we have the event just for you.

While all games are welcome, here are some suggestions for tonight:

American Mah Jongg -- whether you are a beginner or a seasoned pro, we guarantee that there will be a table (or two) for people to play and mingle.

Cribbage -- a lot of people are picking up this game, because it is so awesome.  Do you have a cribbage board?  If so, be sure to bring it :)

Sequence -- Have you played this game before?  The rules are simple but I warn you that it is quite addicting.

We'll be meeting at the Panera in Waltham.  Panera offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a light meal and conversation. The bakery-cafe offers innovative salads and sandwiches, delicious baked goods and healthy frozen shakes.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are Panera. The food is very good, so it will be hard to resist!

Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Note that due to limited space we may place a limit on attendees if too many people sign up (or cancel it if we don't get any at all!)

We will practice together, play and study theory.

Usually we get quite a few beginners, so if you are just starting don't be shy, you definitely can join us. If you have been playing for some time I am sure you will find a few helpful ideas as well. If the level will be very different then we might divide it to two groups eventually.

Half of the class time is dedicated to a consecutive curriculum. We try to choose themes that are relevant to everybody in the class. We might talk about some aspects of technique, or reading, or theory etc. The other half of the class time we usually help students with their individual issues and questions.

We see this class as a supportive and motivational environment for your self-teaching process. There are two experienced guitar teachers (Anastasiya Dumma and David Lee), both Berklee grads, who are ready to answer all your questions and suggest new things to practice!

This is PAY-WHAT-YOU-WANT class. We kindly ask you to support your teachers and Westland Guitars that provided the space. Online donations feel a bit inconvenient (sorry), so you can contribute when you come to the class.
results.how_to_find_us: Westland Guitars is quite easy to find, I believe. For those of you who are familiar with the area it is very close to Whole Foods (across the street) and Symphony Hall. 54B is in the basement and it has its own dedicated entrance.
results.name: Let's make one more step towards guitar mastery.

group.name: Health Nuts of the South Shore Meetup

results.description:
Directors of South Shore Dancers will show you some basic dance steps so you can join in at our dance. Lesson is free. If you want to stay for the dance which begins at 7:30 pm, the cost is $12.00 for entry, which includes a bountiful snack table and non-alcoholic beverages.

At 7:30 pm the dance begins with an intermediate-level dance lesson. You're certainly welcome to try that too, but if it seems a little too advanced at the point, it's a great time to grab some goodies from the snack table and do a little mingling and introduce yourself. Then at 8:00 pm the general dancing begins. Each night includes a couple of line dances, some ladies' choice dances, and a 1/2 hour dance host program, where several men (and perhaps a lady) will be identified as a dance host and anyone is welcome to ask for a dance.


We also have a nightly waltz or fox trot mixer. In the mixer the ladies line up and the men come up to escort each lady around the floor for one turn, then drop them off at the end of the line and start all over a gain. It's a great way to meet some of the other dancers, and also to practice your skills. Don't hesitate to jump in line, and just let your partner know "I'm new at all this" if that's the case.


Each month's dance has a "theme", and dancers are encouraged (but not required!) to dress accordingly. Our theme for November is "Be True to Your School", so wear clothes in your school colors or wear a school tie or jacket if you have those.
results.how_to_find_us: Cushing Memorial Hall is on route 123 in Norwell center.

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
The Forbidden Room

Directed by Guy Maddin and Evan Johnson. With Roy Dupuis, Clara Furey, Louis Negin
Canada 2015, DCP, color, 128 min

'Guy Maddin’s The Forbidden Room is a hilarious nesting doll of lost cinema'


Teaming up with a co-director for the first time in fellow Winnipegian visual effects artist Evan Johnson, Maddin bursts forth withThe Forbidden Room into unexplored aesthetic and structural territory even as he arrives ultimately at the rawest, most poetically Maddinesque object in a career already brimming with unfiltered discharges from the id: a film with an increasingly decaying memory of itself. Longtime Maddin regular Louis Negin materializes onscreen to hold a sermon on bathing rituals, the bubbles in the tub segue into deep ocean waters, and a nervous crew of underwater explorers idles under tons of marine pressure until suddenly a bearded jungle man emerges from a vent to divulge his story of indoctrination into a wolf-human clan—and that is only the first fifteen minutes of the movie. The Forbidden Room continues down a radioactive live wire of narrative convolution, rarely surfacing for air from its starting point, a perverse game of exquisite corpse that alternately evokes frantic channel hopping and the subterranean logic of the human subconscious. Transitions grow more and more deranged (at one point, we enter the daydream of a slain man’s moustache), protagonists swap out every few minutes, and the same actors reappear in as many as five ludicrous iterations. Most remarkably, Maddin and Johnson have cooked up a truly one-of-a-kind hybrid of high-definition digital and organic analog filmmaking, an aggressive fusion that makes their epileptic montage appear as though the surface of a boiling broth.

Preceded by

Elms

Directed by Guy Maddin and Evan Johnson
Canada 2014, digital video, color, 3 min

Guy Maddin, along with collaborator Evan Johnson, repurposes found footage to explore different themes related to Winnipeg, which in this eerie segment centers on the dying elm tree as symbol for both the rise and fall of the city.

Louis Riel for Dinner

Directed by Drew Christie. With Guy Maddin
Canada 2014, video, b/w, 3 min

An animated collaboration, narrated by Maddin, of a story he allegedly found outside his elementary school as a kid, this short is a tribute to the Canadian folk hero Riel, who is portrayed as an inedible duck in this surreal adaptation.

See you in the Forbidden Room of the movies,

John
results.how_to_find_us: With the Director Present, we'll plan to Meetup before the film at 5:15 with our good friends at Yenching
results.name: The Forbidden Room - Guy Maddin in person

We did it once... people loved it! Its back by popular demand, and Heidi has agreed to host it again at her home in Melrose!

Let's sample cupcakes, and pair them with our favorite wines. Chocolate with Cabernet...Pumpkin with Riesling... Lemon with Chardonnay…
Whats your favorite flavor cupcake and wine pairing?

Please bring a few of your favorite cupcakes to sample (made by you, or purchased) and a bottle of one of your favorite wines, red or white. It's not necessary to bring a lot of cupcakes unless you really want to, since we’ll be sharing and sampling.

If you're not into all of that sweetness, savory appetizers are welcome, too, and would probably be a good idea to help keep the sugar-induced walking on the ceiling in check. (In other words, we hope you’ll come, even if you’re not a cupcake fan!)

Please post what kind of cupcakes you plan to bring, so that we can ensure a variety, and if you will be bringing a savory.

The address and parking information will be emailed to those attending a few days before the event.
