results.description:
A great night of music right in downtown Mansfield. Rose Garden Coffehouse is now celebrating their 20th year of bringing live music to their cozy and intimate concert room in the basement of The Congregational Church.

The Featured Artist this time is Roosevelt Dime:

With a whisper or a cry, a long, cool wail or a hot-and-heavy three-part harmony, Brooklyn, N.Y.’s Roosevelt Dime speaks the language of the blues. Their music has been described as “Mardi-Grass,” a bedrock of New Orleans rhythms with driving, melodic banjo, fat-back blues guitar, honky-tonk harmonies and gritty R&B vocals. This will be a blast!


From Roosevelt Dime:


Buy pre-sale tickets for any concert and email a screenshot or copy of your receipt to [masked]. We’ll give you a free digital download of our entire music catalog – four full albums! Sing along in your car, then boogie down at the show.


Advance Tickets Here:

http://www.rosegardenfolk.com/general/seatingnotice-03-Nov.php


PLEASE NOTE: By special arrangement we will have seats reserved for our group for the concert, so if you RSVP, please be courteous and show up!(And buy your ticket at the link above)

ROSE GARDEN FACTS: • We’ve been presenting shows continuously since 1989 • Fully staffed by volunteers • Smoke and alcohol free; wheelchair accessible • Home-baked desserts and hot/cold drinks of the season • Advance ticket sales only available through our website; tickets at door if shows not sold out in advance • In the event of a sellout, we reserve the right to sell your advance sale tickets after 7:50 pm if you have not arrived.
results.name: Roosevelt Dime @ Rose Garden (4 free albums)

results.description:
I’m hosting a concert at my house! 
I hope you can come!

The date: Saturday, November 14, 2015 
The time: 7:30 PM 
The price: The suggested donation is $15. 
All monies go directly to the performers.

How to request seats:

Please email me at [masked]. 
Please tell me: (1) How many seats you want; (2) Your name; (3) Your email address; (4) Your phone number.

I have 20 seats available on a first-to-email-me, first served basis. 
After the first 20, I will put folks on a waiting list. 
I will let you know if you have seats or were put on the waiting list. 
If there is a cancellation and you are next on the waiting list, I will let you know ASAP that you have seats.

I will email you with the address.

The cat: I have a 12-year-old Balinese female named Fermata. She will be sequestered during the concert, but folks with allergies to cats might want to know that I have one.

Thank you for not smoking anywhere in or near my house.

Refreshments: Please bring a beverage and/or snack to share, at intermission and after the concert.

=====================

The program: Featuring the Lexington Symphony Chamber Players with Alexandra Whitfield, soprano

Serenade by Ernst von Dohnanyi [masked]) 
1. Marcia, allegro

Mignon by Franz Schubert [masked]) arr. Aribert Reimann (b. 1936)

June Op. 51, No. 3 by Mrs. H.H.A. Beach [masked]) 
Chanson d'Amour Op. 21 No. 1 
Mirage Op. 100 No. 1

Trio in G by E.J Moeran [masked]) 
1. Allegretto giovale

O Waly, Waly by Benjamin Britten [masked]) 
Come you not from Newcastle?

Cuatro Madrigales Amatorios by Joaquin Rodrigo [masked]) arr. Andrew Maskiell

Alleluia from 'Exultate, Jubilate" by W.A. Mozart [masked])

=====================

The performers:

Alexandra Whitfield, soprano, possesses an agile voice lending itself to a range of styles from Baroque to contemporary American art songs. With her accessible and versatile sound, Alexandra performs around the Boston area as a soloist, educator, and chorister. Her most recent engagements include solo work with the Boston Ballet and the Cantata Singers Chamber Ensemble. Alexandra earned her Bachelor's degree in mathematics and music at Georgetown University and received her Master of Music degree in Vocal Performance from the Longy School of Music of Bard College in May 2014. At Longy, Alexandra was the only vocalist ever to be awarded the Roman Totenberg Award for stellar academic and artistic achievement and deep commitment to the art of music. She also received second place in NEMPAC's vocal competition, was a prize winner in the Massachusetts bi-annual NATS competition and was a winner in the 2013 Concerto Competition at Longy. Alexandra has sung under the baton of Jonathan McPhee, Murray Kidd, David Hoose, and Simon Carrington. She has participated in masterclasses with Benjamin Zander, Nicholas Pham, and Sondra Kelly. Recent engagements have included work with organizations such as the Treble Chorus of New England, the Athenaeum Museum, the Boston Early Music Festival, Classroom Cantatas, the Norfolk Summer Music Festival, and the Franz Schubert Institut in Vienna, Austria. Alexandra is currently studying with Frank Kelley and is a member of Cantata Singers.

Leah Bartell, violin, has performed recitals throughout the U.S. and Canada and completed a one-month residency in Calcutta, India, teaching violin and performing as a soloist with the Calcutta Foundation Orchestra, an organization dedicated to improving the lives of orphans through music education. As a violinist in the Boston area, Ms. Bartell is a member of the Lexington Symphony, and has performed with symphonies and opera companies throughout New England, including the Vermont Symphony, Opera North, PORT Opera, National Lyric Opera, Emmanuel Music, and Portland Ballet. Ms. Bartell discovered her passion for chamber music while studying with the members of the Lafayette String Quartet at the University of Victoria in British Columbia, where she completed her M.Mus. in violin performance in 1999. As a conductor, Ms. Bartell has worked with young orchestras at New England Conservatory, Longy School of Music, and Boston Youth Symphony Orchestras. She is the music director at the Waldorf School of Lexington and is the founder and music director of the Great Meadows Chamber Orchestra. After a recent open rehearsal of one of Ms. Bartell's ensembles, and audience member wrote, "...this kind of music-making doesn't just happen; it is the product of inspired joy and hard work."

Lisa Kempskie, viola, has a degree in violin performance from UMass Lowell and has done graduate work in music education at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. She freelances on violin and viola throughout the greater Boston area and is currently principal viola of the Lexington Symphony. Lisa directed the elementary and middle school string program in the Winchester Public Schools for 7 years and has since maintained a private studio. She also has studied bow-making, repair, and rehair at the Violin Craftsmanship Institute in New Hampshire, and works as a rehair and repair person for regional string companies as well as many local players. Lisa is a certified music practitioner through the Music for Healing and Transition Program which trains musicians to play individually-tailored live therapeutic music at the bedsides of the sick or dying. She is also on the faculties of the Westford Suzuki School and the Lexington Chamber Music Center. 

Jane Sheena, cello, attended the Royal Academy of Music, London, on a scholarship and graduated in 1986. She won a position to play in the Hong Kong Philharmonic in 1987, playing there until 1991. Moving to San Antonio, Texas, she performed frequently in the San Antonio Symphony and was active as a chamber musician and teacher. Since moving to Boston in 1994, Jane has been enjoying teaching and freelancing. She is a cello teacher at The Waldorf School of Lexington and The Rivers School in Weston. She has been a member of the Lexington Symphony since 2005.

Elizabeth Whitfield, violin, has been a member of the Lexington Symphony since its foundation in 1994. A native of England, she studied at London's Guildhall School of Music & Drama. After graduating, she freelanced in London, playing with Orchestra of St. John's Smith Square, London Sinfonietta, City of London Sinfonia, London Mozart Players and Kent Opera. In 1986, she moved to Boston, and focused on raising her three daughters while playing on a more informal basis until attaining Green Card status and eventually U.S. citizenship, enabling her once more to freelance in and around Boston. A Lexington resident, Liz has been involved in many aspects of the Lexington Symphony, and particularly in furthering the reach of Lexington Symphony's educational outreach program, "Orchestrating Kids Through Classics."
results.name: House concert in Lexington MA

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Please be sure to bring socks with you in order to play!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the only ones there, you'll see us! :) Together In Motion is the name of the place.
results.name: Dodge The Ball! - Play Dodgeball With Us!

results.description:
I’m hosting a concert at my house!
I hope you can come!

The date: Saturday, November 14, 2015
The time: 7:30 PM
The price: The suggested donation is $15.
All monies go directly to the performers.

How to request seats:

Please email me at [masked].
Please tell me: (1) How many seats you want; (2) Your name; (3) Your email address; (4) Your phone number.

I have 7 seats available on a first-to-email-me, first served basis.
After the first 7, I will put folks on a waiting list.
I will let you know if you have seats or were put on the waiting list.
If there is a cancellation and you are next on the waiting list, I will let you know ASAP that you have seats.

I will email you with the address.

The cat: I have a 12-year-old Balinese female named Fermata. She will be sequestered during the concert, but folks with allergies to cats might want to know that I have one.

Thank you for not smoking anywhere in or near my house.

Refreshments: Please bring a beverage and/or snack to share, at intermission and after the concert.

=====================

The program: Featuring the Lexington Symphony Chamber Players with Alexandra Whitfield, soprano

Serenade by Ernst von Dohnanyi [masked])
1. Marcia, allegro

Mignon by Franz Schubert [masked]) arr. Aribert Reimann (b. 1936)

June Op. 51, No. 3 by Mrs. H.H.A. Beach [masked])
Chanson d'Amour Op. 21 No. 1
Mirage Op. 100 No. 1

Trio in G by E.J Moeran [masked])
1. Allegretto giovale

O Waly, Waly by Benjamin Britten [masked])
Come you not from Newcastle?

Cuatro Madrigales Amatorios by Joaquin Rodrigo [masked]) arr. Andrew Maskiell

Alleluia from 'Exultate, Jubilate" by W.A. Mozart [masked])

=====================

The performers:

Alexandra Whitfield, soprano, possesses an agile voice lending itself to a range of styles from Baroque to contemporary American art songs. With her accessible and versatile sound, Alexandra performs around the Boston area as a soloist, educator, and chorister. Her most recent engagements include solo work with the Boston Ballet and the Cantata Singers Chamber Ensemble. Alexandra earned her Bachelor's degree in mathematics and music at Georgetown University and received her Master of Music degree in Vocal Performance from the Longy School of Music of Bard College in May 2014. At Longy, Alexandra was the only vocalist ever to be awarded the Roman Totenberg Award for stellar academic and artistic achievement and deep commitment to the art of music. She also received second place in NEMPAC's vocal competition, was a prize winner in the Massachusetts bi-annual NATS competition and was a winner in the 2013 Concerto Competition at Longy. Alexandra has sung under the baton of Jonathan McPhee, Murray Kidd, David Hoose, and Simon Carrington. She has participated in masterclasses with Benjamin Zander, Nicholas Pham, and Sondra Kelly. Recent engagements have included work with organizations such as the Treble Chorus of New England, the Athenaeum Museum, the Boston Early Music Festival, Classroom Cantatas, the Norfolk Summer Music Festival, and the Franz Schubert Institut in Vienna, Austria. Alexandra is currently studying with Frank Kelley and is a member of Cantata Singers.

Leah Bartell, violin, has performed recitals throughout the U.S. and Canada and completed a one-month residency in Calcutta, India, teaching violin and performing as a soloist with the Calcutta Foundation Orchestra, an organization dedicated to improving the lives of orphans through music education. As a violinist in the Boston area, Ms. Bartell is a member of the Lexington Symphony, and has performed with symphonies and opera companies throughout New England, including the Vermont Symphony, Opera North, PORT Opera, National Lyric Opera, Emmanuel Music, and Portland Ballet. Ms. Bartell discovered her passion for chamber music while studying with the members of the Lafayette String Quartet at the University of Victoria in British Columbia, where she completed her M.Mus. in violin performance in 1999. As a conductor, Ms. Bartell has worked with young orchestras at New England Conservatory, Longy School of Music, and Boston Youth Symphony Orchestras. She is the music director at the Waldorf School of Lexington and is the founder and music director of the Great Meadows Chamber Orchestra. After a recent open rehearsal of one of Ms. Bartell's ensembles, and audience member wrote, "...this kind of music-making doesn't just happen; it is the product of inspired joy and hard work."

Lisa Kempskie, viola, has a degree in violin performance from UMass Lowell and has done graduate work in music education at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. She freelances on violin and viola throughout the greater Boston area and is currently principal viola of the Lexington Symphony. Lisa directed the elementary and middle school string program in the Winchester Public Schools for 7 years and has since maintained a private studio. She also has studied bow-making, repair, and rehair at the Violin Craftsmanship Institute in New Hampshire, and works as a rehair and repair person for regional string companies as well as many local players. Lisa is a certified music practitioner through the Music for Healing and Transition Program which trains musicians to play individually-tailored live therapeutic music at the bedsides of the sick or dying. She is also on the faculties of the Westford Suzuki School and the Lexington Chamber Music Center. 

Jane Sheena, cello, attended the Royal Academy of Music, London, on a scholarship and graduated in 1986. She won a position to play in the Hong Kong Philharmonic in 1987, playing there until 1991. Moving to San Antonio, Texas, she performed frequently in the San Antonio Symphony and was active as a chamber musician and teacher. Since moving to Boston in 1994, Jane has been enjoying teaching and freelancing. She is a cello teacher at The Waldorf School of Lexington and The Rivers School in Weston. She has been a member of the Lexington Symphony since 2005.

Elizabeth Whitfield, violin, has been a member of the Lexington Symphony since its foundation in 1994. A native of England, she studied at London's Guildhall School of Music & Drama. After graduating, she freelanced in London, playing with Orchestra of St. John's Smith Square, London Sinfonietta, City of London Sinfonia, London Mozart Players and Kent Opera. In 1986, she moved to Boston, and focused on raising her three daughters while playing on a more informal basis until attaining Green Card status and eventually U.S. citizenship, enabling her once more to freelance in and around Boston. A Lexington resident, Liz has been involved in many aspects of the Lexington Symphony, and particularly in furthering the reach of Lexington Symphony's educational outreach program, "Orchestrating Kids Through Classics."

Cafe Mangal has generously agreed to allow us to have a Blind Wine Tasting at their wonderful BYOB restaurant.  Bring a wine from Turkey, Greece, Lebanon or Syria to enjoy with a delicious prix fix menu.   Wine shops that carry some of these wines include Gordon's in Waltham, Wine Warehouse in Framingham and Cambridge Wine & Spirits (although none of them carry any Turkish wines. I found some Turkish wines at Sevan Groceries on Mount Auburn Street, in Watertown, if anyone wants to venture there).


Dinner includes a mezze plate, your choice of Chicken, Lamb or Fish entree and Baklava for dessert all for $63 including corkage fee, tax and tip.  When you respond please make your entree selection.

The 3 main courses you can choose from are:


Chicken Breast Dardanelle    
Natural chicken breast cut into small pieces baked in a casserole with artichokes; Greek Extra virgin olive oil, tomatoes, French feta cheese, olives, scallions & oregano 

Pistachio Crusted Baked Haddock                
Haddock filet baked with pistachios and chardonnay served with arugula radish salad, sautéed green beans & baby carrots

Kasibeyaz Lamb Shish Kebab            
Grilled Lamb Loin Skewer with Assorted Bell Peppers and Onions Marinated in Aleppo peppers, olive oil, milk, tomato - red pepper paste & garlic, served with rice pilaf and vegetables  


Limit 12 people - please try to bring exact change in cash so that the end of the meal goes smoothly.

Hoşgeldiniz!

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Liberty and Lafayette. We will use the steep Falling Waters Trail to reach the ridge and then follow Francoia Ridge Trail to first reach Lincoln and then Lafayette. From there we will use Greenleaf Trail to descend to the now closed AMC Greenleaf Hut and then Old Bridle Path to get back to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 8.9 miles and climb about 4,200 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 30 minutes to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/6-Mt-Lafayette-5260--7-Mt-Lincoln-5089


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.160747571000456&lon=-71.64432749599968#.VjgreYTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION (E.G. KAHTOOLA MICROSPIKES OR HILLSOUND TRAIL CRAMPONS), AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Falling Waters Trailhead which is located on the east side of 93 N north of Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 137 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 7 minutes to drive there. 

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/AuuXaoQoSqN2


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
Bushwhack Middle (3500') and East Scar (3621') on the NH100/NH3K lists

This is one of the toughest bushwhacks in the Whites. 

Note: We will NOT be hiking the full Scar Ridge and will NOT be going to West Scar on the NE100 Highest list. 

Details:

Meet at 8:00 am at East Pond Trailhead on Tripoli Road if the road is still open (otherwise we'll start from the Kanc). We'll hike up the East Pond Loop Tr before heading uphill to the summit of Middle Scar, before dropping down a bit to make our way to East Scar since the woods are less thick there. From there we'll figure out the best route back to our cars. 

Who is This Trip For: 

Experienced bushwhackers seeking a challenge, or hikers working on the NH100 Highest or NH3K Lists. You should be adept at using a map and compass to navigate. This isn't an instructional trip. 

Note: I will be screening people who sign up to make sure you have the appropriate experience. 

Directions: 

We'll meet the East Pond Trailhead at 8:00am on Tripoli Rd. Please be on time. 

Clothing and Gear Advice: 

Standard 3 season day hiking gear adjusted for cooler autumn weather, including a headlamp, compass, layers, etc. SERIOUSLY. Bring a headlamp, a bright one!

Hunting season has begun. Wear a blaze orange hat or vest if you have one. If you don't, this might be a good time to opportunity to get some blaze orange clothing for future bushwhacking trips. 

Don't wear any clothing that you don't want ripped up, including rain gear. It's a bushwhack. 

Eye protection and gloves are STRONGLY recommended. You also want to wear long pants and a long sleeve short to avoid getting torn to pieces by the vegetation.

Trip Objectives:

To get the most out of this trip, we all need to work together as a team and come prepared with a good mental image of what the terrain will look like along our route. 

This won't be one of those AMC trips where you follow a leader who does all of the off-trail navigation for you. Nope: I hope we'll all be looking for the best, most energy efficient way through the woods and up the mountains together, guided in part by compass bearings, altitude (altimeters), and by reading the terrain we see (and expect to see.) 

Don't bring a GPS. It takes the challenge out of climbing these peaks using our own wits. 

We've kept this trip small to make sure everyone has a chance to participate in the off-trail navigation process. If you plan to cancel off this hike, please let me know as soon as possible so I can swap in someone on the wait list to fill your spot. 

For purposes of establishing a common language for communicating compass bearings, please make sure you bring a compass that has an adjustable declination, so we can all communicate using bearings based on true north (also called map north and grid north) and NOT magnetic north. Adding and subtracting declinations is a source of great confusion in groups, so we'll just nip it in the bud and make sure we're reading from the same sheet of music. 

Some links:

A recommended declination adjustable compass
http://www.rei.com/product/408150/suunto-m-3d-leader-compass

Instructions on taking true north bearings
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Navigate-with-a-Map-and-Compass/step3/Taking-a-Bearing-on-a-Map/

Caltopo online mapping tool. Can print PDF maps with 1:24,000 USGS scale
http://caltopo.com

results.description:
This is a moderately paced hike up the "Marion Davis" trail to the top of South Pack, then follow the Wapack trail through the valley to reach Cliff trail, which takes us up North Pack. [We can break for lunch there], then finish the loop and come back down to the Wapack trail to South Pack, then back to the cars. Total elevation gain is 2000 ft. 
Viewpoints show the rolling hills of Southern New Hampshire, as well as a view of Mount Monadnock from the Wapack trail. 

The goal is to have a walk in the mountain, enjoy whatever is left of the foliage. 

The trip will run rain or shine, unless weather conditions are extreme, in which case we will call it off. Depending on temperatures that day, cold weather gear (extra layers, hats, gloves) will be needed 

Details on meeting time and exact location with be shared with approved participants

Register here: https://regi.amcboston.org/1060

results.description:
Ipswich River offers more than 12 miles of trails that invite you to explore the forests, meadows, and wetlands. A drumlin and esker, key landscape features, were formed by a glacier 15,000 years ago. Boulders stacked to create arches and a grotto setting, constructed in 1905, provide an adventurous walk along the Rockery Trail.

The sanctuary fee is $4.00 for non-Audubon membersand free to members.

Duration: Approximately 3 to 4 hours, but please remember that this is an estimate and can vary greatly according to the group, weather and trail conditions.

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. I am committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up. 

Please note this is not a beginners’ hike. It is for intermediate level hikers and beginning hikers who keep in fit condition doing other things. You should be in good enough physical condition to keep up and stay with the group going at a moderate pace. Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared.Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme temperature cancels.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

 By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

results.description:
Movements originate as intentions in our brain, which has a “blue print” for every act we intend to do. When we suffer from pain or frustration with our performance, we need to change the brain’s habitual patterns that activate and organize the muscles. Dr. Feldenkrais developed a method to do just that. It replaces habits that limit our physical, mental, emotional and professional life with new, more beneficial ones that will become as natural to us as the ones we gave up. We can all find ways to feel pleasure, power and vitality in our actions, as we did in the early stages of life.

What is the Feldenkrais Method®?  The Feldenkrais method has given people the means to make the activities of daily life more pleasurable and pain free and to expand the range and quality of movement regardless of age or physical condition. It helps people with chronic pain, movement disorders and neurological issues. It is also a well known tool for performers - musicians, dancers and athletes to improve their performance.


How is it done? The movement lessons, called “Awareness Through Movement®” are done lying on the floor, sitting or standing. They are easy and gentle and are designed to alert you to previously overlooked details of your movements. They train you to sense trouble before it becomes a crisis and gives you the tools to reverse the damaging process. The private lessons, called “Functional Integration®”, are hands on treatments. They are used when the person needs individual attention to overcome the problems.


What you can expect from the Feldenkrais Method:

• Reduced pain

• New ways of coping with stress

• Increased range of movement

• Enhanced athletic and artistic performance

• Prevention of performance related injuries

• Greater ease and pleasure in physical activities

• Quicker recovery of abilities following trauma

• Increased mental clarity

• A sense of vitality and power


COST:  Early bird $90 by Nov 1. $110 after. 

Sign up with a friend and save more $75/each by Nov 1.


REGISTER HERE: http://www.tiffanysankary.com/Ease_Power_and_Vitality.html


Aliza Stewart has been practicing the Feldenkrais Method since 1986. She is an internationally known Trainer, teaching new Feldenkrais teachers across the U.S., Europe, South America and Israel.


She has given classes, workshops and presentations for many institutions and organizations including The Johns Hopkins applied Physics Laboratory, TheKennedy Krieger Institute, The Maryland Medical and Chirurgical Society, The Universoty of Wisconsin in Madison and The University of Maryland Medical School.

Originally trained as a concert pianist, Aliza has a great affinity for the needs and problems of performers. She has taught Feldenkrais classes at the Peabody Conservatory and at the Mannes College of Music. She is in residence at the Marlboro Chamber Music Festival and the Yellow Barn Music Festival, and has taught workshops in for musicians in Berlin and Vienna.


What Students Say:

“Aliza provided me with many tools to free myself from the constant aches and pains. With the fusion of 4 vertebrae 25 years ago, I tolerated back, hip and neck pains and curtail my exercise and parenting activities. Aliza led me to change my habits so that I can take pleasure in the most mundane aspects of life that previously caused me pain.” - Gail Fishman – museum manager

"I've tried many healing modalities besides allopathic medicine, but none have been as transformative as the Feldenkrais Method. Among Feldenkrais practitioners, Aliza Stewart is recognized as a master and it is no wonder. Her classes and private sessions are not only highly effective at reducing and eliminating pain, but they also foster an overall sense of vitality, power and expanded possibilities." - Hannah VoDinh – guitarist

“I never skied better in my life than this past week. I know that Feldenkrais and Aliza’s work with me for the last two years are behind my getting better and having more fun at this stage of my life, 72 years old and still learning”. - Diana Jacquot – retired restaurateur and financial planner

“Aliza’s intelligence and commitment make her a real master of the Feldenkrais method. As a classical musician, I suffered chronic pain for several years and Aliza helped eradicate it within months. Aliza Stewart and the Feldenkrais method changed my life.” – Heather Storeng, violist

<a href="http://www.movementandcreativity.com"></a>

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting.

------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before?  

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun 

http://www.projectfreerun.com/

Join us on court this Sunday at 11 a.m. for the start of this spring season's Beginner Level Group Tennis Clinics conducted by highly experience tennis professionals.


This weekly (every Sunday) series of group clinics is a 6-session, 9 hour (each session runs 90 minutes) series of clinics designed for beginner level tennis players.

The fundamentals of tennis will be covered throughout the series in a format that will utilize precise tennis drills and clear description of fundamentally correct tennis technique to reinforce these tennis essentials with each participating player.

Each 90-minute session in the series will include: warm-up exercises; dynamic stretching; cardio drills; skill-building tennis drills; description and demonstration of fundamentally sound tennis strokes.

Each participant will get to hit many balls during drills under the watchful eye of the supervising tennis pro.

We have priced this series of clinics at the handsomely discounted, cost-friendly rate of just $135. That averages a very low $15/hr/player.

Learn the game of tennis or improve your beginner level strokes. In these clinics, you'll do just that and, at the same time, increase your enjoyment of tennis.

Hi All! 

Changing things up a bit, let's meet a little earlier at the Harvard Museum of Natural History! The Harvard Museum of Natural History was created in 1998 as the “public face” of three research museums — the Museum of Comparative Zoology, the Harvard Mineralogical and Geological Museum, and the Harvard University Herbaria (I did not know this was a word).

 It hosts a variety of natural world exhibitions, including a large glass flower collection. The museum is on the Harvard University campus and is the school's most visited attraction. 

The details for this event: The museum entrance is free before 12:00PM for all Massachusetts residents with proof of residency so bring your state ID (or rental agreement?). Otherwise the museum is $10 for students and $12 for adults. If you have a Harvard ID, are a Harvard Museums member, a teacher, an ASTC passport program member, or apart of active duty military, the entrance is also free. 

Drawing is encouraged in the galleries, but the use of clay, paints, pastels, and chalk is not permitted. So bring your pens and colored pencils! I think that about covers it, hope to see you there!

results.description:
Our November topic: Gratitude? What's that?

November is the month we gather around a table with our family and friends and give thanks for the blessings in our lives ... or is it? I think we need to pick this apart a little bit, don't you:

--Is it possible to be grateful every day, or are we kidding ourselves? In our increasingly entitled society, do we know what giving thanks means anymore, or are we just going through the motions?

--Is gratitude reflected upon with humility more authentic than gratitude shared on Facebook/Instagram/Twitter?

--What does it say about us that on the one day we Americans ritualize gratitude, some of us (a great deal of us, actually) would much rather stand in a line at the door of a closed mall in anticipation of 'Black Friday' sales and the illusion of the ultimate bargain than spend time with loved ones?

--Can people only be truly grateful who are going through some kind of hardship (financial, medical, social, etc.)? Is gratitude something that is, largely, situational?

--Who are we (you!) grateful to? To whom are we expressing this gratitude?

Break bread with us in November and be ready to share your thoughts/musings/anecdotes about gratitude.

Hope to see you there!

===============================================


Brunch Menu

Brunch for Thought FAQs <-- REVISED - PLEASE READ

results.description:
This is the regular meetup on Sundays at noon at Brooklyn Boulders in Somerville.  Meet by the first table/bench thing by the entrance.  Hopefully we'll get a good variety of climbing interests coming so that everyone can follow their climbing passion!

(Credit to Francesco Cardiello for the information below):
BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!  If you are looking for a partner, or just want to get your climb on, join us for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to toprope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. This meetup assures you'll meet a partner to climb with.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): Day Pass - $25 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
Texture is the most enduring and ubiquitous underpinning of form creating a calming, meditative and appealing world for both the eye and mind. (Lynda Lehmann)


Announcement: I am going to offer two more sessions before I head out of town until mid December. This week we will explore nature near the city. Next week we will venture into one of the great neighborhoods for an urban landscape session. I hope you can join the fun while the weather holds!

This week we will be going Belle Island Marsh. I went last weekend on my birthday to scout this location an was astonished to discover such a visually rich marsh right in our back yard. The variety of textures available in this small space will keep us very busy for 3 hours. I will design specific assignments for you to 


Wild Wind moving through the grasses of the marsh.

Seeing the beauty of the marsh requires slowing down and noticing the more subtle colors, and textures. I went on an overcast day and it was low tide, not ideal conditions. Still I was delighted with the intriguing images I was able to capture and you can too.  One of the skills of taking your photography to the next level is to be able to take better photos in all lighting conditions.

Even if you have visited this nature reserve before, I think you will see it with fresh eyes as a result of this workshop.  We will delve into the visual characteristics that result in more dramatic compositions. 

Look how many different layers of texture you can capture in a single image. The tide was out this day, but will be in when we visit this weekend.

You can see the Boston Skyline in the distance. 

Tide will be in while we are there so you can also capture reflections. I checked the tide schedule just to be sure it matches our visit.

There are also many subjects that would be excellent from closeup and macro shots. Bring your tripod if you have one.


During this workshop we will focus on:

• Best camera settings for capturing the details of a variety of textures in one shot.

• New composition strategies for dramatic and subtle landscapes that evoke a mood and tell a story.

• How to use design elements of symmetrical and asymmetrical composition to achieve balance and wholeness.

• How to adjust your camera setting if you want to work in aperture and shutter priority. ( I will do a special talk for a small group of you who want extra time on this topic. I will walk you through taking your camera off Auto and help you understand the relationship between ISO, Aperture and Shutter priority.)

• More advanced participants will work on creative seeing assignments for making  your images more interesting and captivating using dynamic tension.


One fun aspect of this location, it is  right beneath a flight path to Logan. If you want to turn your camera toward the sky.... use shutter priority. 

This week is easy walking, flat paths. Located 5 minutes from the Suffolk Downs T stop on the Blue line. And there is plenty of free parking. 

End of day blast of bright sunlight changed everything in an instant.  I hope to see you there on Sunday. Just RSVP now to get a spot in the class. I am keeping the group small again this week so I can spend extra time with each of you.

Suzanne

results.name: The Beauty & Mystery of  Belle Isle Marsh: Focus on Texture and Light

results.description:
"A window of opportunity won't open itself." Dave Weinbaum

Even those of us living in the suburbs care about, and have a role to play in, the anti-racism movement. From frustration, fear, and anger to empathy, passion, and solidarity, this work can bring up a lot for everyone. Our supportive group discussions can help us get some clarity, perspective, and encouragement through the process. We will focus on a different topic each meeting, sometimes including films and discussions about printed materials …encouraging member feedback to help guide future topics.

The mission of this group discussion series is to promote awareness of inequality, to build community, and to develop skills that address dismantling racism and oppression within a diverse, compassionate, and culturally sensitive environment.

All are welcome: People of Color, white people…people new to this topic and those involved and active for many years. Come with questions and/or experience to share with others wanting to learn more.

Hosted by Deb and Carlin, members of Boston Knapsack Anti-Racism Group.

If interested, please join Knapsack and RSVP to this meeting date (with no further obligations). Please change your RSVP if your plans change and you can no longer come so we can plan accordingly.

Feel free to post questions here too.
We look forward to hearing from you!
results.name: Anti-Racism in the ‘Burbs (Medfield, MA)

results.description:
Groups are wonderful! They help bolster your commitment and motivation, they supply you with opportunities to get ahead on your journey, and they provide support from the other members.
But when it comes to EFT, groups are even more wonderful! Not only is there a synergy created between the tappers increasing the potency of healing received, but even when the tapping isn't related to your particular problem, you still bet to borrow benefits from it!

Note that the amount of people allowed in the tapping circle is limited to 10. If you need to cancel your reservation, please do so at least 3 days in advance so that someone else can come in to the event...

Please arrive early. Doors will open 15 minutes ahead of time and the tapping circle will begin promptly at 2pm. Late comers will not be allowed in. A late arrival not only disrupts the flow of the circle, shatters the feeling of safety so necessary in healing work, but can also prevent the facilitator from pacing the circle well.

See you soon!

results.description:
An Introduction to The Diamond Approach - The Inner Flame for the Spiritual Journey 


*"Let yourself be silently drawn by the stronger pull of what you really love" **Rumi* *What calls you to a path? *What feels true to you? What states or experiences resonate with a "Yes!” in your body and being and call you to bring them more fully into daily life? Perhaps it is a simple experience of nature, a sunset, or moments of solitude, time with family, or those that share your practices and way of life...

For some it is a soft call to the unknown, or the passionate search for what it would mean to live vibrantly, authentically in each moment. You are invited to come and reflect with your hosts on what sparks your curiosity and flame for Truth and realization, in an afternoon called:
The Diamond Approach is a contemporary teaching that integrates psychological and spiritual understanding into one thread of living knowledge. The work is not a form of therapy, but a teaching to awaken and develop Presence, and move beyond our conditioning so we may live our deepest Truths of realization.
The Diamond Approach has been taught in Boston for 20 years and for over 40 years in the USA. For more information visit www.ridhwan.org <" class="linkified">http://www.ridhwan.org/>;;.

*" The truth is your very nature" A.H. Almaas* 

This free introduction will be offered by teachers-in-training and experienced students of the school. It will include a presentation, experiential exercises to offer a “taste” of the work, and time for questions, inquiry, and discussion. All are welcome

For more information, contact: Grant Trewenack ***** ph:[masked] RSVP is not necessary but appreciated!

www.foodicinehealth.org

November 15,[masked]:00-5:00 pm
Seaport Hotel Boston Action Kitchen

A VERY GLUTEN-FREE CHRISTMAS, CHANUKAH, & KWANZA

Chef-Tony Maws, Cragie on Main, Cambridge, MA
Dietitian-Melinda Dennis, Celiac Center, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, MA
To Sign-Up Go To:
http://www.eventbrite.com/o/foodicine-health-inc-8383710024

Have you been diagnosed with a chronic illness or a food allergy and think that your diet is now destined to be limited or boring? Are you unsure of what you can or cannot eat on your low-carbohydrate/low-sugar, low-fat, low-salt, gluten-free or other “Special Diet” and are looking for ways to eat fabulous, yummy food? Do you just want to learn new cooking techniques or new recipes that include ingredients that your physician or dietitian has told you are included on your prescribed diet? Then the Foodicine Health “Yes, You Can Eat!” Cooking Series is for you! Join expert Dietitians and Celebrity Chefs as they discuss ways to:

Change your lifestyle and diet to help you to improve your health; Cook delicious meals that fit into your dietary requirements, are fun and easy to prepare, and will delight your friends and family.

Each class will focus on a different “Special Diet” that is associated with a different chronic illness or food allergy. You can taste the recipes that the Chefs are cooking and will leave these classes with dietary information regarding your specific medical condition or allergy and with recipes that you will love to prepare at home! You will also learn that your future is destined to be gourmet, fun and delicious!

Since the 2000 election, on average over half of the candidates for the Massachusetts legislature have not have an opponent in the general election. With a stat like that, it is easy to conclude that we live in a democracy in name only. In 2016, we want to fix that in as many races as we can. We ran two State Representative candidates in 2014. In 2016, we know we can run many more candidates if we all work together. We want your help to identify, get on the ballot and support at least 20 candidates. Whether it is contacting members, revising our platform or supporting our candidates, there is much to do.

We ran two State Representative candidates in 2014. In 2016, we know we can run many more candidates if we all work together.

We want your help to identify, get on the ballot and support at least 20 candidates. Whether it is contacting members, revising our platform or supporting our candidates, there is much to do.

Following up on our successful candidate recruitment meeting last Sunday, we have two campaign meetings upcoming: Nov. 15th and Dec. 6th. We would appreciate it if you registered so we know how large to make the reservations.

(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

results.description:
The oldest, established, permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and environs.

Please join the Fresh Pond Community walkers + five other meetup groups for this delightful sunset walk. 

Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 3 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Weekly Community Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :11/15@3:30pm

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean and Arthur
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
YOUR EXCLUSIVE 2015 RED SOX NATIVES EVENT will be hosted by the Red Sox Natives.

This event needs a volunteer event host.

A volunteer Event Host will arrive early, get a table and we strongly suggest you arrive 1/2 hour before 4 :25pm Game Time and ask the hostess for the Red Sox Natives party.

Please join us at The Scoreboard in Woburn for a Patriots Game Viewing!

Scoreboard will be busy and does not take reservations. Please arrive early if you wish to be seated at a group table. Seating is not guaranteed. Guests can watch the game in the bar area or near any of the abundant Big Screen TVs in Scoreboard.

Stay for part or all of the game. Wear your Patriots gear.

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers Scoreboard staff may take credit cards and there will be no group bill if you speak to your server first. If you are seated at a group table you may have a group bill. Everyone is responsible for their own food and drinks.

The Red Sox Natives have been organizing Sports viewing parties over the last several years with guests from several other invited groups attending. We have had a blast with up to 80 people attending at various locations in Boston, Woburn and Wakefield.

Scoreboard has been one of our venues for watching Patriots, Red Sox, Bruins and Celtics games over the past several years.

If you have never been to Scoreboard it is located at 15 Middlesex Canal Park next to the Hotel and Lowes Showcase Cinema off Route 128 in Woburn. Scoreboard has over 50 high definition and plasma TVs ranging in size from 50 to 92 inches. Parking is free. More info at http://www.tpsscoreboard.com

We hope to see you there!

Go Pats!
results.name: Patriots Game Viewing at Scoreboard - vs New York Giants

results.description:
Our October/November Travel Book Club is here and hosted by the Boston chapter this round! We’ve been reading Lauren Juliff's "How Not to Travel the World"!

“How Not to Travel The World is about following your dreams, no matter how many curveballs life throws at you. It’s about learning to get out of your comfort zone, finding the humour in messed up situations, and falling in love with life on the road.”

https://www.sheswanderful.com/blog/2015/10/08/wanderful-reads-how-not-to-travel-the-world/


Buy your copy from Amazon to support Wanderful!

It's not required that you finish the book by the time we meet, but we hope you do, and are ready to have some fun discussion about this book, along with some light guided questions.

Here’s how it works:


• Thursday, October 7th: Book was introduced on the Wanderful site here. Purchase your copy of the book, on your kindle or in hardcopy at the link here to support Wanderful.

• November: Wanderful women around the world discuss the book in person with their local chapter. 


Wanderful Boston will be meeting Sunday November 15th at the Capital One 360 Café at 4:30pm. 

Location: The cafe is located at 310 Harrison Ave, Boston, MA. 

Remember, if you're driving, parking is free on Sundays! This café is about a 5 minute walk from the Tufts Medical stop on the orange line.

• Beginning of December: Announcement of our next book!
results.name: Wanderful Book Club! (November)

group.name: Wanderful Women Who Travel: Boston Chapter

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

group.name: The Light Within - Yoga, Reiki, Meditation - Dorchester MA

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 38-53 - SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description: Lets discuss our first book My Brilliant Friend, by Elena Ferrante and meet eachother over a glass of wine and some food!
results.name: Discuss our book and maybe have a meal!

group.name: New to Boston, Late 20s - early 30s, Women's Book Club

results.description:
RUMINATING ON THE NEW WATER PARADIGM

Sunday, November 15th, 6:00-9:00 p.m. 

If you attended our Restoring Water Cycles to Reverse Global Warming conference October 16th-18th at Tufts University, you may have found some of the ideas presented about the New Water Paradigm to be incredibly eye-opening but also quite complex! Are you still trying to process some of this information, or do you have any lingering questions? If so, join us for a group discussion in which we'll review what we learned, help each other refine our collective understanding, and explore further questions. 

If you didn't attend our conference and are interested in discovering what the New Water Paradigm is all about and how it can help us cool the planet, we encourage you to come! 

This will be a potluck-style gathering, so please bring a dish or beverage for sharing! 

We look forward to seeing you there.

Cheers, 

Biodiversity for a Livable Climate
results.how_to_find_us: From Broadway, turn right on Fayette Street, then left onto Fayette Park (a private way). Helen's house is toward the end, on the right.
results.name: Ruminating on the New Water Paradigm

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
